LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not brought there by formal summons, as I had been; they simply arrived, drawn by the magnetic pull of his legendary parties, the whispers of his wealth, and the mystery that clung to his name like the summer fog over Long Island Sound.  

That evening, the air was thick with laughter and the clinking of glasses, the gardens alive with the rustle of silk and the glow of lanterns strung between the trees. Women in shimmering dresses floated past, their voices rising and falling like the tide, while men in white flannels stood in clusters, their conversations punctuated by bursts of laughter that dissolved into the night.  

No one seemed to know their host. They spoke of him in hushed tones, weaving rumors as intricate as the champagne bubbles that rose in their glasses. Some said he had killed a man; others insisted he was a German spy during the war. A few, with knowing smiles, claimed he was related to royalty. But no one truly knew.  

And yet, Gatsby himself was nowhere to be seen. He moved through his own parties like a ghost, a figure glimpsed at the edge of a crowd, always just out of reach. I wondered if he preferred it that way—if the spectacle he had created was meant to be admired from a distance, like one of his own dazzling fireworks, brilliant but fleeting.  

When I finally met him, much later that summer, I understood why he had remained hidden. There was something unbearably fragile beneath his polished charm, a longing so raw it seemed to vibrate in the air between us. He was a man who had built an empire of light and music, yet who stood alone at its center, waiting for something—or someone—that might never come.  

That first night, though, I knew none of this. I only knew that I had stepped into a dream, one that would unravel before my eyes before the summer was through.

events.title: Nick Reunites with Jordan and Hears Gossip About Gatsby
detailed_summary: Feeling intensely embarrassed and contemplating getting drunk, Nick spots Jordan Baker emerging from the house.
Jordan stood at the top of the steps, observing the garden with detached curiosity.
Nick felt compelled to join someone to avoid awkwardness.
He greeted her loudly across the garden.
Jordan acknowledged him casually, mentioning she thought he might be present since he lived nearby.
She briefly held his hand while listening to two girls in identical yellow dresses who approached.
The girls greeted Jordan, offering commiserations for her recent loss in a golf tournament final.
One girl mentioned they had met Jordan at a previous party about a month ago.
Jordan observed that the girl had changed her hair color since then.
As the girls departed, Jordan linked her arm with Nick's, and they walked down into the garden.
They accepted cocktails from a passing tray and sat at a table with the two girls in yellow and three unnamed men.
Jordan asked one of the girls if she attended Gatsby's parties frequently.
The girl confirmed she attended the last one where they met.
Her companion, Lucille, added that she enjoyed the parties because she could act freely and always had fun.
Lucille recounted tearing her dress at a previous party and receiving a replacement gown from Gatsby worth $265 after he asked for her details.
Jordan inquired if Lucille kept the expensive gown, which Lucille confirmed, noting it needed alterations.
The other girl remarked on the peculiarity of Gatsby's generosity, suggesting he avoids confrontation.
When Nick asked who they were discussing, the name 'Gatsby' was mentioned.
The two girls and Jordan leaned in together conspiratorially.
One girl whispered a rumor that Gatsby had killed someone.
This rumor created a palpable thrill among the group, including the three men.
Lucille countered sceptically, suggesting it was more likely he was a German spy during the war.
One of the men claimed confirmation from someone who supposedly grew up with Gatsby in Germany.
The first girl dismissed the spy theory, pointing out Gatsby served in the American army.
She intensified the murder rumor, suggesting observing Gatsby when he thinks he's unnoticed reveals his guilt.
Both Lucille and the first girl shivered, and the group instinctively looked around for Gatsby.
Nick mused on the romantic speculation surrounding Gatsby, noting even those usually indiscreet whispered about him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

events.text_segment:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
Welcome or not, I found it necessary to attach myself to someone before I should begin to address cordial remarks to the passersby.
“Hello!” I roared, advancing toward her. My voice seemed unnaturally loud across the garden.
“I thought you might be here,” she responded absently as I came up. “I remembered you lived next door to—”
She held my hand impersonally, as a promise that she’d take care of me in a minute, and gave ear to two girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps.
“Hello!” they cried together. “Sorry you didn’t win.”
That was for the golf tournament. She had lost in the finals the week before.
“You don’t know who we are,” said one of the girls in yellow, “but we met you here about a month ago.”
“You’ve dyed your hair since then,” remarked Jordan, and I started, but the girls had moved casually on and her remark was addressed to the premature moon, produced like the supper, no doubt, out of a caterer’s basket. With Jordan’s slender golden arm resting in mine, we descended the steps and sauntered about the garden. A tray of cocktails floated at us through the twilight, and we sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each one introduced to us as Mr. Mumble.
“Do you come to these parties often?” inquired Jordan of the girl beside her.
“The last one was the one I met you at,” answered the girl, in an alert confident voice. She turned to her companion: “Wasn’t it for you, Lucille?”
It was for Lucille, too.
“I like to come,” Lucille said. “I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it.”
“Did you keep it?” asked Jordan.
“Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars.”
“There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that,” said the other girl eagerly. “He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody.”
“Who doesn’t?” I inquired.
“Gatsby. Somebody told me—”
The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.
“Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.”
A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.
“I don’t think it’s so much that,” argued Lucille sceptically; “It’s more that he was a German spy during the war.”
One of the men nodded in confirmation.
“I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany,” he assured us positively.
“Oh, no,” said the first girl, “it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war.” As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. “You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man.”
She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

Here is the complete text segment from *The Great Gatsby* by F. Scott Fitzgerald, corresponding to the provided metadata:  

---

**text_segment**:  

*I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.*  

*Wanting to hear the sound of my own voice, I greeted her.*  

*“Hello!” I roared, advancing toward her.*  

*My voice seemed unnaturally loud across the garden. I had a faint hope that she would point her finger at me, but she didn’t. Instead, she raised her eyebrows a little and smiled as if she were amused at something I had said. I walked up to her, still holding out my hand. She gave it a brief, impersonal squeeze and then dropped it.*  

*“I thought you might be here,” she said absently. “I remembered you lived next door to—”*  

*She held my hand impersonally, as a promise that she’d take care of me in a minute, and gave ear to two girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps.*  

*“Hello!” they cried together. “Sorry you didn’t win.”*  

*That was for the golf tournament. She had lost in the finals the week before.*  

*“You don’t know who we are,” said one of the girls in yellow, “but we met you here about a month ago.”*  

*“You’ve dyed your hair since then,” remarked Jordan, and I started, but the girls had moved casually on and her remark was addressed to the premature moon, produced like the supper, no doubt, out of a caterer’s basket. With Jordan’s slender golden arm resting in mine, we descended the steps and sauntered about the garden. A tray of cocktails floated at us through the twilight, and we sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each one introduced to us as Mr. Mumble.*  

*“Do you come to these parties often?” inquired Jordan of the girl beside her.*  

*“The last one was the one I met you at,” answered the girl, in an alert, confident voice. She turned to her companion: “Wasn’t it for you, Lucille?”*  

*It was for Lucille, too.*  

*“I like to come,” Lucille said. “I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it.”*  

*“Did you keep it?” asked Jordan.*  

*“Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars.”*  

*“There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that,” said the other girl eagerly. “He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody.”*  

*“Who doesn’t?” I inquired.*  

*“Gatsby. Somebody told me—”*  

*The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.*  

*“Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.”*  

*A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.*  

*“I don’t think it’s so much that,” argued Lucille skeptically; “it’s more that he was a German spy during the war.”*  

*One of the men nodded in confirmation.*  

*“I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany,” he assured us positively.*  

*“Oh, no,” said the first girl, “it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war.” As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. “You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man.”*  

*She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.*  

---

This passage captures the gossip, intrigue, and mystique surrounding Jay Gatsby, as well as the social dynamics of the party. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.  

The sight of her froze me in my tracks. There was something so effortlessly commanding about her—the way she held herself, the cool detachment in her gaze—that made my own humiliation feel trivial. She wore a dress of pale lavender, the fabric catching the evening light as if it were woven from twilight itself. Her chin was tilted just slightly, as though the world beneath her was something to be observed, not participated in.  

I hesitated, torn between my wounded pride and the magnetic pull of her presence. Before I could decide whether to retreat or approach, she turned her head and saw me. A slow, knowing smile curved her lips, as if she had been expecting me all along.  

“Well, if it isn’t the man of the hour,” she drawled, her voice laced with amusement. “Or should I say, the man of the *mis*adventure?”  

I winced. So she had seen—or at least heard about—my disastrous attempt to impress Daisy with some absurd story that had unraveled the moment I opened my mouth. The memory burned fresh in my mind, and I felt the heat rise to my cheeks again.  

Jordan, however, seemed to take my discomfort as entertainment. She descended the steps with deliberate grace, stopping just close enough to make me acutely aware of the space between us.  

“You know,” she said, studying me with those sharp, gold-flecked eyes, “most men would have slunk off to nurse their wounds in private. But here you are, still lingering like a lost puppy.”  

I bristled at the comparison but couldn’t deny the truth in it. “I was just leaving,” I muttered, though my feet refused to move.  

She laughed softly, a sound like dry leaves skittering across pavement. “No, you weren’t. You were about to drown yourself in gin to forget how foolish you looked.”  

There was no point in arguing. Jordan had an uncanny ability to strip away pretense, leaving only the raw, uncomfortable truth.  

“And what would you suggest I do instead?” I asked, half-defiant, half-resigned.  

She considered me for a long moment, then shrugged one slender shoulder. “Stay. Own it. The worst thing you can do is let them see it bothers you.”  

I frowned. “That’s your grand advice?”  

“It’s kept *me* afloat,” she replied, her smile turning wry. “People respect confidence, even if it’s faked. And besides—” She leaned in slightly, her voice dropping to a conspiratorial murmur. “—Daisy’s already forgotten all about it. She’s too busy being charmed by Gatsby’s latest grand gesture.”  

I followed her gaze back toward the house, where the muffled sounds of laughter and music spilled from the open windows. The party was in full swing, oblivious to my momentary disgrace.  

Jordan straightened, brushing an invisible speck from her sleeve. “So? Are you going to hide, or are you going to come back inside and pretend you meant to be the evening’s comic relief?”  

I exhaled, feeling some of the tension leave my shoulders. There was something oddly reassuring about her bluntness—no false sympathy, no empty reassurances. Just the unvarnished truth, delivered with a smirk.  

“Fine,” I said, squaring my shoulders. “But if anyone asks, I was *absolutely* joking.”  

Jordan’s grin widened. “There you go. Now you’re learning.”  

And with that, she turned and glided back toward the house, leaving me to follow—or not.  

After a moment’s hesitation, I did.

events.title: Encounter with the Owl-Eyed Man in the Library
detailed_summary: As the first supper service began, Jordan invited Nick to join her group at another table.
This group consisted of three married couples and Jordan's persistent, suggestive undergraduate escort, representing East Egg's reserved nobility contrasting with West Egg's flamboyance.
After about thirty minutes, Jordan expressed boredom with the polite company and suggested they leave to find Gatsby, noting Nick's unease about not having met him.
They searched the crowded bar, the top of the steps, and the veranda without finding Gatsby.
They decided to try an imposing door and entered a grand, oak-panelled library, likely imported.
Inside, a stout, middle-aged man with large spectacles sat drunk on a table, staring intently at the bookshelves.
He turned excitedly upon their entrance and scrutinized Jordan.
He demanded their opinion about the books.
Waving towards the shelves, he declared he had already ascertained their authenticity – they were real books with pages.
He expressed surprise, having expected them to be convincing fakes, like cardboard props.
To prove his point, he fetched a volume of the 'Stoddard Lectures'.
He triumphantly presented it as genuine printed matter, comparing Gatsby to the theatrical producer Belasco for his thorough realism.
He noted the pages weren't cut, implying they hadn't been read, but still praised the effort.
He quickly returned the book, warning that removing one might cause the whole library facade to collapse.
He inquired if Nick and Jordan were brought by someone, stating most guests were, including himself.
He mentioned being brought by a Mrs. Claud Roosevelt whom he met the previous night.
He admitted he'd been drunk for a week and hoped sitting in the library would sober him up.
When asked if it worked, he was unsure, having only been there an hour, and started to talk about the real books again.
Nick and Jordan confirmed he'd already told them, shook his hand formally, and left the library.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.

events.text_segment:
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo, and obviously under the impression that sooner or later Jordan was going to yield him up her person to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of rambling, this party had preserved a dignified homogeneity, and assumed to itself the function of representing the staid nobility of the countryside—East Egg condescending to West Egg and carefully on guard against its spectroscopic gaiety.
“Let’s get out,” whispered Jordan, after a somehow wasteful and inappropriate half-hour; “this is much too polite for me.”
We got up, and she explained that we were going to find the host: I had never met him, she said, and it was making me uneasy. The undergraduate nodded in a cynical, melancholy way.
The bar, where we glanced first, was crowded, but Gatsby was not there. She couldn’t find him from the top of the steps, and he wasn’t on the veranda. On a chance we tried an important-looking door, and walked into a high Gothic library, panelled with carved English oak, and probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.
A stout, middle-aged man, with enormous owl-eyed spectacles, was sitting somewhat drunk on the edge of a great table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. As we entered he wheeled excitedly around and examined Jordan from head to foot.
“What do you think?” he demanded impetuously.
“About what?”
He waved his hand toward the bookshelves.
“About that. As a matter of fact you needn’t bother to ascertain. I ascertained. They’re real.”
“The books?”
He nodded.
“Absolutely real—have pages and everything. I thought they’d be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they’re absolutely real. Pages and—Here! Lemme show you.”
Taking our scepticism for granted, he rushed to the bookcases and returned with Volume One of the Stoddard Lectures.
“See!” he cried triumphantly. “It’s a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?”
He snatched the book from me and replaced it hastily on its shelf, muttering that if one brick was removed the whole library was liable to collapse.
“Who brought you?” he demanded. “Or did you just come? I was brought. Most people were brought.”
Jordan looked at him alertly, cheerfully, without answering.
“I was brought by a woman named Roosevelt,” he continued. “Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? I met her somewhere last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.”
“Has it?”
“A little bit, I think. I can’t tell yet. I’ve only been here an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They’re real. They’re—”
“You told us.”

**text_segment**:  
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo and obviously under the impression that sooner or later Jordan was going to yield him up her person to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of rambling, this party had preserved a dignified homogeneity, and assumed to itself the function of representing the staid nobility of the countryside—East Egg condescending to West Egg, and carefully on guard against its spectroscopic gayety.  

“Let’s get out,” whispered Jordan, after a somehow wasteful and inappropriate half-hour. “This is much too polite for me.”  

We got up, and she explained that we were going to find the host: I had never met him, she said, and it was making me uneasy. The undergraduate nodded in a cynical, melancholy way.  

The bar, where we glanced first, was crowded, but Gatsby was not there. She couldn’t find him from the top of the steps, and he wasn’t on the veranda. On a chance we tried an important-looking door, and walked into a high Gothic library, panelled with carved English oak, and probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.  

A stout, middle-aged man, with enormous owl-eyed spectacles, was sitting somewhat drunk on the edge of a great table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. As we entered he wheeled excitedly around and examined Jordan from head to foot.  

“What do you think?” he demanded impetuously.  

“About what?”  

He waved his hand toward the book-shelves.  

“About that. As a matter of fact you needn’t bother to ascertain. I ascertained. They’re real.”  

“The books?”  

He nodded.  

“Absolutely real—have pages and everything. I thought they’d be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they’re absolutely real. Pages and—Here! Lemme show you.”  

Taking our scepticism for granted, he rushed to the bookcases and returned with Volume One of the “Stoddard Lectures.”  

“See!” he cried triumphantly. “It’s a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?”  

He snatched the book from me and replaced it hastily on its shelf, muttering that if one brick was removed the whole library was liable to collapse.  

“Who brought you?” he demanded. “Or did you just come? I was brought. Most people were brought.”  

Jordan looked at him alertly, cheerfully, without answering.  

“I was brought by a woman named Roosevelt,” he continued. “Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? I met her somewhere last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.”  

“Has it?”  

“A little bit, I think. I can’t tell yet. I’ve only been here an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They’re real. They’re—”  

“You told us.”  

We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. The air was thick with laughter and the clinking of glasses, the scent of rich food mingling with the perfume of the flowers that lined the pathways. As we made our way through the crowd, I couldn’t help but marvel at the spectacle before me—the shimmering dresses, the sharp tuxedos, the way the lanterns cast a golden glow over everything, as if the entire evening had been dipped in liquid gold.

Jordan’s party consisted of a lively mix of people, some I recognized from earlier in the evening, others entirely new to me. There was a man with a booming laugh who seemed to dominate the conversation, a woman with a voice like honey who leaned in close to whisper secrets, and a pair of twins who mirrored each other’s movements with eerie precision. Jordan introduced me with a casual wave of her hand, and though I caught a few curious glances, no one seemed particularly interested in probing my background. It was as if my presence was just another ornament in Gatsby’s grand display, easily accepted and just as easily forgotten.

The food was extravagant—platters of oysters, roasted meats glistening with glaze, delicate pastries that dissolved on the tongue. Champagne flowed freely, and I found myself caught up in the rhythm of the evening, the way the conversation ebbed and flowed like the tide. At one point, someone mentioned Gatsby’s name, and the table fell into a hush before erupting into speculation. 

“They say he killed a man once,” murmured the woman with the honeyed voice. 

“No, no, he’s a war hero,” countered the booming man. “Decorated by the Germans themselves!” 

Jordan merely smirked, swirling her drink as if she alone knew the truth. I wanted to ask her, to press for answers, but the moment passed as quickly as it had come, the conversation shifting to horse races and the latest scandal in New York society. 

As the night wore on, the garden seemed to grow more enchanted, the stars above brighter, the music sweeter. I lost track of time, caught between the warmth of the champagne and the magnetic pull of the party. It wasn’t until the first hints of midnight approached that I realized how deeply I’d been drawn into Gatsby’s world—a world where anything seemed possible, where the ordinary rules didn’t apply, and where the man himself remained just out of reach, a shadow behind the glittering facade. 

And then, as if on cue, the whispers began again. Gatsby was coming. The second supper was about to begin.

events.title: Nick Unknowingly Meets Gatsby
detailed_summary: Back outside, dancing had commenced on the garden's canvas platform.
Various couples danced, some awkwardly, some fashionably, while single girls danced alone or briefly joined the orchestra.
By midnight, the party's energy escalated; performers sang, guests performed 'stunts,' and laughter filled the air.
The girls in yellow performed a costumed act, and champagne was served in large glasses.
The moon cast a silvery light on the Sound.
Nick, still with Jordan, sat at a table with a man his age and a boisterous young woman.
Nick began enjoying himself after drinking champagne, finding the scene transformed.
During a pause, the man at the table smiled at Nick.
The man commented on Nick's familiar face and asked if he served in the First Division during the war.
Nick confirmed his service in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.
The man shared his own service in the Sixteenth Infantry.
They briefly reminisced about villages in France.
The man mentioned living nearby, having just bought a hydroplane he planned to test.
He invited Nick to join him for a flight along the shore the next morning.
Nick agreed and asked for a time, receiving a flexible response.
Just as Nick was about to ask the man's name, Jordan interjected, asking if he was having a better time.
Nick confirmed he was enjoying himself more and turned back to the man.
He explained the party was unusual for him as he hadn't met the host, gesturing towards his own house nearby and mentioning Gatsby sent the invitation.
The man looked momentarily confused.
He then identified himself suddenly as Gatsby.
Nick expressed surprise and apologized.
Gatsby, calling Nick 'old sport,' apologized for being a poor host, assuming Nick already knew who he was.
Gatsby offered a remarkable, reassuring smile that seemed to embrace the world before focusing entirely on Nick with immense favor.
The smile conveyed deep understanding and belief, projecting the exact positive impression Nick hoped to make.
The smile vanished abruptly, revealing an elegant man around thirty, whose formal speech bordered on absurd, suggesting carefully chosen words.
Nick realized Gatsby had been selecting his words deliberately even before the introduction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps.

events.text_segment:
There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps. By midnight the hilarity had increased. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing “stunts” all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. A pair of stage twins, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, did a baby act in costume, and champagne was served in glasses bigger than finger-bowls. The moon had risen higher, and floating in the Sound was a triangle of silver scales, trembling a little to the stiff, tinny drip of the banjoes on the lawn.
I was still with Jordan Baker. We were sitting at a table with a man of about my age and a rowdy little girl, who gave way upon the slightest provocation to uncontrollable laughter. I was enjoying myself now. I had taken two finger-bowls of champagne, and the scene had changed before my eyes into something significant, elemental, and profound.
At a lull in the entertainment the man looked at me and smiled.
“Your face is familiar,” he said politely. “Weren’t you in the First Division during the war?”
“Why yes. I was in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.”
“I was in the Sixteenth until June nineteen-eighteen. I knew I’d seen you somewhere before.”
We talked for a moment about some wet, grey little villages in France. Evidently he lived in this vicinity, for he told me that he had just bought a hydroplane, and was going to try it out in the morning.
“Want to go with me, old sport? Just near the shore along the Sound.”
“What time?”
“Any time that suits you best.”
It was on the tip of my tongue to ask his name when Jordan looked around and smiled.
“Having a gay time now?” she inquired.
“Much better.” I turned again to my new acquaintance. “This is an unusual party for me. I haven’t even seen the host. I live over there—” I waved my hand at the invisible hedge in the distance, “and this man Gatsby sent over his chauffeur with an invitation.”
For a moment he looked at me as if he failed to understand.
“I’m Gatsby,” he said suddenly.
“What!” I exclaimed. “Oh, I beg your pardon.”
“I thought you knew, old sport. I’m afraid I’m not a very good host.”
He smiled understandingly—much more than understandingly. It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it, that you may come across four or five times in life. It faced—or seemed to face—the whole eternal world for an instant, and then concentrated on you with an irresistible prejudice in your favour. It understood you just so far as you wanted to be understood, believed in you as you would like to believe in yourself, and assured you that it had precisely the impression of you that, at your best, you hoped to convey. Precisely at that point it vanished—and I was looking at an elegant young roughneck, a year or two over thirty, whose elaborate formality of speech just missed being absurd. Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The scene was a whirl of motion and color, a dizzying spectacle of gaiety that seemed to pulse with the very heartbeat of the summer night. The air was thick with the mingled scents of perfume, champagne, and the faint salt breeze drifting in from the Sound. The orchestra, perched on a raised platform draped in ivy, played with feverish energy, their music swelling and dipping like the tide, urging the dancers into ever more frenzied movements.  

The old men, their faces flushed with drink and exertion, clutched the hands of young girls who laughed too loudly, their eyes bright with a kind of desperate merriment. There was something grotesque in the way these aging figures, their dignity long since abandoned, stumbled through the steps, their partners swaying like marionettes in their grasp. The girls, for their part, seemed neither to notice nor to care, lost in the thrill of the moment, their laughter ringing like chimes above the music.  

In the corners, the more sophisticated couples moved with a studied elegance, their bodies pressed close, their steps precise and deliberate. They whispered to one another, their lips brushing ears, their smiles knowing and secretive. These were the ones who understood the game, who knew that the dance was merely a prelude to something darker, more intoxicating. Their eyes flickered over the crowd, assessing, judging, always aware of their own superiority.  

And then there were the single girls—dozens of them—flitting about like moths drawn to the brightest lights. Some danced alone, their arms raised above their heads, their bodies swaying to rhythms only they could hear. Others, emboldened by champagne, seized instruments from the band, plucking at banjo strings or tapping out erratic beats on the drums, their laughter mingling with the music in a discordant symphony. They were the life of the party, these girls, their energy boundless, their joy unchecked—or so it seemed.  

For beneath the surface of all this revelry, there was a hollowness, a sense that none of it mattered. The laughter was too loud, the dancing too frantic, the music too insistent. It was as if they were all trying to outrun something—some unnameable dread that lurked just beyond the glow of the lanterns. The night stretched on, endless and ephemeral, a dream from which they would all too soon awake.  

And yet, for now, they danced. They danced as though the world outside Gatsby’s garden did not exist, as though time itself had paused to let them revel in their own fleeting glory. The stars above watched indifferently, their light cold and distant, while below, the party burned ever brighter, a fire that would consume itself before the dawn.

events.title: Gatsby's Enigma and Detachment
detailed_summary: Immediately after Gatsby identified himself, a butler arrived with news of a phone call from Chicago.
Gatsby excused himself courteously to the group, urging Nick to ask for anything he needed and promising to return later.
Once Gatsby left, Nick turned to Jordan, expressing his surprise, admitting he had pictured Gatsby as older and heavier.
Nick asked Jordan about Gatsby's identity and origins.
Jordan replied simply that he's 'just a man named Gatsby.'
When pressed about Gatsby's background and profession, Jordan mentioned Gatsby once claimed to be an Oxford graduate.
This briefly created a potential background for Gatsby, but Jordan immediately expressed her disbelief.
Her sceptical tone reminded Nick of the earlier rumor about Gatsby killing someone, fueling his curiosity.
Nick reflected that humble origins would be understandable, but a young man mysteriously appearing and buying a palace seemed implausible.
Jordan steered the conversation away from specifics, stating she likes Gatsby's large, intimate parties where privacy is possible.
The orchestra leader announced the next piece, requested by Gatsby: Vladimir Tostoff's 'Jazz History of the World,' described as a recent sensation.
As the music started, Nick observed Gatsby standing alone on the steps, watching the party with an approving gaze.
Nick noted Gatsby's healthy appearance and neat grooming, seeing nothing sinister.
He speculated Gatsby's sobriety might set him apart, as Gatsby seemed to grow more formal while the guests became more uninhibited.
After the music ended, guests engaged in playful, intimate behavior, but no one approached Gatsby in such a manner; he remained separate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that someone would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.

events.text_segment:
Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a small bow that included each of us in turn.
“If you want anything just ask for it, old sport,” he urged me. “Excuse me. I will rejoin you later.”
When he was gone I turned immediately to Jordan—constrained to assure her of my surprise. I had expected that Mr. Gatsby would be a florid and corpulent person in his middle years.
“Who is he?” I demanded. “Do you know?”
“He’s just a man named Gatsby.”
“Where is he from, I mean? And what does he do?”
“Now you’re started on the subject,” she answered with a wan smile. “Well, he told me once he was an Oxford man.”
A dim background started to take shape behind him, but at her next remark it faded away.
“However, I don’t believe it.”
“Why not?”
“I don’t know,” she insisted, “I just don’t think he went there.”
Something in her tone reminded me of the other girl’s “I think he killed a man,” and had the effect of stimulating my curiosity. I would have accepted without question the information that Gatsby sprang from the swamps of Louisiana or from the lower East Side of New York. That was comprehensible. But young men didn’t—at least in my provincial inexperience I believed they didn’t—drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island Sound.
“Anyhow, he gives large parties,” said Jordan, changing the subject with an urban distaste for the concrete. “And I like large parties. They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy.”
There was the boom of a bass drum, and the voice of the orchestra leader rang out suddenly above the echolalia of the garden.
“Ladies and gentlemen,” he cried. “At the request of Mr. Gatsby we are going to play for you Mr. Vladmir Tostoff’s latest work, which attracted so much attention at Carnegie Hall last May. If you read the papers you know there was a big sensation.” He smiled with jovial condescension, and added: “Some sensation!” Whereupon everybody laughed.
“The piece is known,” he concluded lustily, “as ‘Vladmir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World!’ ”
The nature of Mr. Tostoff’s composition eluded me, because just as it began my eyes fell on Gatsby, standing alone on the marble steps and looking from one group to another with approving eyes. His tanned skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests, for it seemed to me that he grew more correct as the fraternal hilarity increased. When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that someone would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.

I would have accepted without question the information that Gatsby sprang from the swamps of Louisiana or from the lower East Side of New York. That was comprehensible. But young men didn’t—at least in my provincial inexperience I believed they didn’t—drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island Sound.  

“Anyhow, he gives large parties,” said Jordan, changing the subject with an urban distaste for the concrete. “And I like large parties. They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy.”  

Before the orchestra leader had time to announce the next piece, there was a burst of chatter like the pop of a cork, and the leader himself was on his feet.  

“If you please,” he cried, “Mr. Gatsby would like to request the honor of playing Vladimir Tostoff’s latest work, which attracted so much attention at Carnegie Hall last May. If you’ve read the papers you know there was a big sensation.” He smiled with jovial condescension, and added: “Some sensation!” Whereupon everybody laughed.  

“The piece is known,” he concluded lustily, “as ‘Vladimir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World.’”  

The nature of Mr. Tostoff’s composition eluded me, because just as it began my eyes fell on Gatsby, standing alone on the marble steps and looking from one group to another with approving eyes. His tanned skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests, for it seemed to me that he grew more correct as the fraternal hilarity increased. When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that some one would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself, a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. Gatsby excused himself with a slight, apologetic bow, his expression unreadable beneath the practiced charm. The guests murmured among themselves, their curiosity piqued by this interruption—another thread in the ever-tightening web of mystery surrounding their host.  

As he disappeared into the house, the party resumed its rhythm, the music swelling once more, the laughter rising like bubbles in champagne. Yet the air seemed charged with an unspoken question: Who was Jay Gatsby, really?  

Nick Carraway, standing near the edge of the veranda, watched the scene with quiet fascination. He had seen the momentary flicker in Gatsby’s eyes—something between apprehension and resolve—before he had turned away. It was the first crack in the polished façade, the first hint that beneath the dazzling spectacle of wealth and revelry, there was a man with secrets.  

Daisy Buchanan, luminous in her white dress, turned to Nick with a small, knowing smile. “He’s always vanishing like that,” she said, her voice light but edged with something deeper. “One moment he’s here, the next—gone. It’s as if he’s afraid someone might catch him standing still.”  

Tom Buchanan, standing nearby with a drink in hand, snorted. “Probably some shady business deal,” he muttered. “You don’t get that kind of money playing by the rules.” His words were heavy with disdain, but there was an undercurrent of something else—resentment, perhaps, or envy.  

Nick said nothing. He had seen the way Gatsby looked at Daisy, the way his entire being seemed to strain toward her like a flower toward the sun. There was more to this man than reckless extravagance and whispered rumors.  

When Gatsby returned some minutes later, his composure was flawless once more, his smile effortless. But Nick noticed the way his fingers tightened briefly around his glass before he raised it in a toast to the night, to the company, to the endless, glittering future he seemed to believe in so fervently.  

The call from Chicago was forgotten by most, just another fleeting detail in the whirl of the evening. But for Nick, it lingered—a reminder that behind the grand illusions, there were real stakes, real dangers.  

Later, as the party dwindled and the first light of dawn crept over the water, Gatsby stood alone on the terrace, staring out at the green light across the bay. Nick hesitated, then joined him.  

“Quite a night,” Nick ventured.  

Gatsby turned, his face unguarded for once, weary and strangely young. “Yes,” he said softly. “But they always are, aren’t they?”  

And in that moment, Nick understood that for all his wealth, his parties, his carefully constructed persona, Jay Gatsby was still waiting for something—something just out of reach, something that no amount of money could buy.  

The telephone call, the green light, the longing in his eyes—it was all part of the same story, a story of hope and desperation, of dreams pursued at any cost.  

And Nick wondered, not for the first time, how it would end.

events.title: Gatsby Summons Jordan; Party Degenerates
detailed_summary: Gatsby's butler approached Nick and Jordan.
He requested Miss Baker speak with Mr. Gatsby privately.
Jordan reacted with surprise but slowly rose and followed the butler towards the house.
Nick observed Jordan's athletic posture and movement, likening her walk to one developed on golf courses.
Alone again near two a.m., Nick heard intriguing, confused sounds from a room overlooking the terrace.
Avoiding Jordan's former escort (now occupied with chorus girls), Nick went inside the room.
The large room was crowded.
One of the girls in yellow played piano while a red-haired chorus singer performed.
The singer, heavily intoxicated with champagne, had become overwhelmed with sadness, weeping as she sang.
She filled pauses with sobs before continuing in a trembling voice, tears making black streaks through her makeup.
A guest humorously suggested she sing the tear tracks, causing her to collapse into a chair in a drunken sleep.
A nearby girl explained to Nick that the singer had argued with her supposed husband.
Nick looked around and noticed many women arguing with men presumed to be their husbands.
Even Jordan's sophisticated East Egg group had descended into discord; one man focused intently on an actress while his wife alternated between feigned indifference and angry, whispered accusations.
Resistance to leaving wasn't limited to men; two sober men were being urged to leave by their indignant wives.
The wives complained loudly to each other about their husbands wanting to leave whenever they were having fun, calling it selfish.
One husband pointed out sheepishly that they were nearly the last guests, as the orchestra had already left.
Despite the wives' agreement on the husbands' unbelievable behavior, the argument ended with the men physically carrying their protesting wives out.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I beg your pardon.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

events.text_segment:
“I beg your pardon.”
Gatsby’s butler was suddenly standing beside us.
“Miss Baker?” he inquired. “I beg your pardon, but Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you alone.”
“With me?” she exclaimed in surprise.
“Yes, madame.”
She got up slowly, raising her eyebrows at me in astonishment, and followed the butler toward the house. I noticed that she wore her evening-dress, all her dresses, like sports clothes—there was a jauntiness about her movements as if she had first learned to walk upon golf courses on clean, crisp mornings.
I was alone and it was almost two. For some time confused and intriguing sounds had issued from a long, many-windowed room which overhung the terrace. Eluding Jordan’s undergraduate, who was now engaged in an obstetrical conversation with two chorus girls, and who implored me to join him, I went inside.
The large room was full of people. One of the girls in yellow was playing the piano, and beside her stood a tall, red-haired young lady from a famous chorus, engaged in song. She had drunk a quantity of champagne, and during the course of her song she had decided, ineptly, that everything was very, very sad—she was not only singing, she was weeping too. Whenever there was a pause in the song she filled it with gasping, broken sobs, and then took up the lyric again in a quavering soprano. The tears coursed down her cheeks—not freely, however, for when they came into contact with her heavily beaded eyelashes they assumed an inky colour, and pursued the rest of their way in slow black rivulets. A humorous suggestion was made that she sing the notes on her face, whereupon she threw up her hands, sank into a chair, and went off into a deep vinous sleep.
“She had a fight with a man who says he’s her husband,” explained a girl at my elbow.
I looked around. Most of the remaining women were now having fights with men said to be their husbands. Even Jordan’s party, the quartet from East Egg, were rent asunder by dissension. One of the men was talking with curious intensity to a young actress, and his wife, after attempting to laugh at the situation in a dignified and indifferent way, broke down entirely and resorted to flank attacks—at intervals she appeared suddenly at his side like an angry diamond, and hissed: “You promised!” into his ear.
The reluctance to go home was not confined to wayward men. The hall was at present occupied by two deplorably sober men and their highly indignant wives. The wives were sympathizing with each other in slightly raised voices.
“Whenever he sees I’m having a good time he wants to go home.”
“Never heard anything so selfish in my life.”
“We’re always the first ones to leave.”
“So are we.”
“Well, we’re almost the last tonight,” said one of the men sheepishly. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.”
In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

I noticed that she wore her evening dress, all her dresses, like sports clothes—there was a jauntiness about her movements as if she had first learned to walk upon golf courses on clean, crisp mornings.  

I was alone and it was almost two o’clock. For some time confused and intriguing sounds had issued from a long, many-windowed room which overhung the terrace. A humorous suggestion was made that she sing the notes on her face, whereupon she threw up her hands, sank into a chair, and went off into a deep vinous sleep.

I looked around. Most of the remaining women were now having fights with men said to be their husbands. Even Jordan’s party, the quartet from East Egg, were rent asunder by dissension. One of the men was talking with curious intensity to a young actress, and his wife, after attempting to laugh at the situation in a dignified and indifferent way, broke down entirely and resorted to flank attacks—at intervals she appeared suddenly at his side like an angry diamond, and hissed: “You promised!” into his ear.  

The reluctance to go home was not confined to wayward men. The hall was at present occupied by two deplorably sober men and their highly indignant wives. The wives were sympathizing with each other in slightly raised voices.  

“Whenever he sees I’m having a good time he wants to go home.”  

“Never heard anything so selfish in my life.”  

“We’re always the first ones to leave.”  

“So are we.”  

“Well, we’re almost the last tonight,” said one of the men sheepishly. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.”  

In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
"I beg your pardon," said Gatsby, his voice low and urgent, as if the words carried more weight than mere politeness. He stood there in the dim glow of the library, his hands clenched at his sides, his eyes fixed on me with an intensity that made the air between us hum with unspoken tension.  

I had stumbled upon him by accident, wandering into the room in search of a quiet retreat from the clamor of his party. The laughter and jazz from downstairs seemed a world away now, muffled by the thick walls and the heavy silence that had settled between us.  

Gatsby’s face was pale, his usual composure frayed at the edges. For a moment, he looked almost like a man caught in a dream, unsure whether he was awake or still lost in some private reverie. Then, just as quickly, the mask slipped back into place—the easy charm, the practiced smile. But I had seen the crack, the briefest flicker of something raw beneath the surface.  

"Didn’t mean to startle you," he said, forcing a laugh that didn’t quite reach his eyes.  

I shook my head, trying to dispel the strange unease that had taken hold of me. "No, it’s—it’s fine. I just didn’t expect anyone to be in here."  

His gaze drifted past me, settling on the rows of untouched books lining the shelves. "Real, aren’t they?" he murmured, more to himself than to me.  

I frowned. "The books?"  

He nodded absently, his fingers brushing the spine of one as if testing its authenticity. "Bought them by the crate. The man said they were genuine—first editions, some of them. Never got around to reading them, though."  

There was something heartbreaking in the admission, in the way he spoke of these beautiful, unread things—another carefully arranged prop in the grand illusion of his life. I wondered how much of Gatsby was real and how much was just another layer of the performance, another role he played to perfection.  

The moment stretched, fragile and uncertain. Then, from downstairs, a burst of laughter shattered the quiet, pulling us both back to the present. Gatsby straightened, his expression smoothing into something more familiar—the gracious host, the man who threw the most extravagant parties in West Egg.  

"You should join the others," he said, gesturing toward the door. "The night’s still young."  

But as I turned to leave, I caught one last glimpse of him—just a man standing alone in a room full of unread books, his smile fading the moment he thought no one was looking.  

And for the first time, I understood that Gatsby, for all his wealth and grandeur, was the loneliest person I had ever met.

events.title: Jordan Hints at Secrets; Nick Departs
detailed_summary: While Nick waited for his hat, Jordan and Gatsby emerged from the library.
Gatsby was speaking earnestly to Jordan but quickly became formal as other guests approached to leave.
Jordan's group called for her from the porch, but she paused to shake Nick's hand.
She whispered that she had just heard something astonishing, asking how long they were in the library (about an hour).
Jordan repeated it was 'simply amazing' but stated she was sworn to secrecy, playfully tantalizing Nick.
Yawning, she invited Nick to visit, providing her aunt's name (Mrs. Sigourney Howard) for the phone book.
She hurried away, waving goodbye as she joined her party.
Feeling slightly embarrassed for staying so late on his first visit, Nick joined the remaining guests around Gatsby.
He wanted to explain his earlier search for Gatsby and apologize for not recognizing him.
Gatsby dismissed it warmly, telling Nick not to worry.
He reminded Nick about their hydroplane plans for nine the next morning, his familiar phrase ('old sport') now feeling less personal.
The butler interrupted, informing Gatsby that Philadelphia was on the phone.
Gatsby instructed the butler to tell them he'd be there shortly and bid Nick good night.
As Nick left, Gatsby's smile made him feel a pleasant significance in being among the last guests.
Gatsby repeated 'Good night, old sport... Good night.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Good night, old sport… Good night.”

events.text_segment:
As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying some last word to her, but the eagerness in his manner tightened abruptly into formality as several people approached him to say goodbye.
Jordan’s party were calling impatiently to her from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake hands.
“I’ve just heard the most amazing thing,” she whispered. “How long were we in there?”
“Why, about an hour.”
“It was… simply amazing,” she repeated abstractedly. “But I swore I wouldn’t tell it and here I am tantalizing you.” She yawned gracefully in my face. “Please come and see me… Phone book… Under the name of Mrs. Sigourney Howard… My aunt…” She was hurrying off as she talked—her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.
Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.
“Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.” The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And don’t forget we’re going up in the hydroplane tomorrow morning, at nine o’clock.”
Then the butler, behind his shoulder:
“Philadelphia wants you on the phone, sir.”
“All right, in a minute. Tell them I’ll be right there… Good night.”
“Good night.”
“Good night.” He smiled—and suddenly there seemed to be a pleasant significance in having been among the last to go, as if he had desired it all the time. “Good night, old sport… Good night.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. There was an air of quiet intensity about them, as though they had just concluded a conversation of great importance. Jordan’s face was composed, yet her eyes held a knowing glint, while Gatsby stood beside her, his usual restless energy momentarily subdued.  

He turned to me with a forced smile, as if trying to mask whatever had transpired behind those closed doors. “Old sport,” he said, his voice oddly strained, “I trust you’ve been enjoying yourself?”  

Before I could answer, Jordan slipped her arm through mine with practiced ease. “We were just discussing the weather,” she said lightly, though her tone suggested anything but.  

Gatsby’s gaze flickered between us, and for a brief moment, I caught a glimpse of something raw and unguarded in his expression—something like desperation. Then, just as quickly, it was gone, replaced by that familiar, polished charm.  

“Of course,” he murmured, stepping back. “The weather. Always a safe topic.”  

The moment passed, and the three of us moved toward the front door, where the night air hung heavy with the scent of blooming flowers and distant jazz. Yet, despite the laughter and music drifting from the party behind us, I couldn’t shake the feeling that something significant had just occurred—something that, like so much in Gatsby’s world, remained just beyond my grasp.  

Jordan squeezed my arm, her smile enigmatic. “Come along, Nick,” she said. “The night is still young.”  

And with that, we stepped into the warm darkness, leaving Gatsby standing alone in the doorway, his figure silhouetted against the golden light of his impossible dream.

events.title: Chaos After the Party: The Car Crash
detailed_summary: Walking down the steps, Nick realized the night wasn't over.
Headlights illuminated a chaotic scene near the road: a new coupé, just departed from Gatsby's, rested in a ditch, missing a wheel.
A damaged wall explained the detached wheel, which was being examined by curious chauffeurs.
The chauffeurs' parked cars blocked the road, causing a cacophony of horns from waiting vehicles.
A man in a duster (recognized by Nick as the Owl-Eyed man from the library) stood dazedly in the road, looking between the wreck and the onlookers.
He explained, with astonishment, that the car went into the ditch.
When asked how it happened, he shrugged, claiming ignorance of mechanics.
Pressed further about hitting the wall, he deflected responsibility, stating he knew almost nothing about driving and only knew 'it happened'.
Bystanders criticized him for driving poorly at night.
He indignantly protested that he wasn't even trying to drive.
A hush fell as bystanders reacted with disbelief and concern about his recklessness.
He clarified he wasn't the driver; another man was in the car.
The crowd reacted with a collective gasp as the car door opened slowly.
After a pause, a pale, unsteady individual emerged from the wreck.
Blinking in the headlights and confused by the horns, he swayed before noticing the Owl-Eyed man.
He calmly asked if they had run out of gas.
Multiple people pointed out the missing wheel.
He stared at the wheel, then looked up as if it fell from the sky, admitting he hadn't noticed they stopped.
After a moment, he straightened up and asked determinedly for directions to a gas station.
Several men explained the wheel was detached from the car.
He suggested backing the car out.
When reminded the wheel was off, he hesitated, then concluded there was 'no harm in trying'.
As the horns reached a peak, Nick turned away and walked home across the lawn.
He glanced back once at Gatsby's house, still lit under the moon, appearing fine despite the recent chaos.
A sense of emptiness emanated from the house, highlighting the solitary figure of Gatsby on the porch, raising his hand in a formal farewell gesture.

events.text_segment:
But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over. Fifty feet from the door a dozen headlights illuminated a bizarre and tumultuous scene. In the ditch beside the road, right side up, but violently shorn of one wheel, rested a new coupé which had left Gatsby’s drive not two minutes before. The sharp jut of a wall accounted for the detachment of the wheel, which was now getting considerable attention from half a dozen curious chauffeurs. However, as they had left their cars blocking the road, a harsh, discordant din from those in the rear had been audible for some time, and added to the already violent confusion of the scene.
A man in a long duster had dismounted from the wreck and now stood in the middle of the road, looking from the car to the tyre and from the tyre to the observers in a pleasant, puzzled way.
“See!” he explained. “It went in the ditch.”
The fact was infinitely astonishing to him, and I recognized first the unusual quality of wonder, and then the man—it was the late patron of Gatsby’s library.
“How’d it happen?”
He shrugged his shoulders.
“I know nothing whatever about mechanics,” he said decisively.
“But how did it happen? Did you run into the wall?”
“Don’t ask me,” said Owl Eyes, washing his hands of the whole matter. “I know very little about driving—next to nothing. It happened, and that’s all I know.”
“Well, if you’re a poor driver you oughtn’t to try driving at night.”
“But I wasn’t even trying,” he explained indignantly, “I wasn’t even trying.”
An awed hush fell upon the bystanders.
“Do you want to commit suicide?”
“You’re lucky it was just a wheel! A bad driver and not even trying!”
“You don’t understand,” explained the criminal. “I wasn’t driving. There’s another man in the car.”
The shock that followed this declaration found voice in a sustained “Ah-h-h!” as the door of the coupé swung slowly open. The crowd—it was now a crowd—stepped back involuntarily, and when the door had opened wide there was a ghostly pause. Then, very gradually, part by part, a pale, dangling individual stepped out of the wreck, pawing tentatively at the ground with a large uncertain dancing shoe.
Blinded by the glare of the headlights and confused by the incessant groaning of the horns, the apparition stood swaying for a moment before he perceived the man in the duster.
“Wha’s matter?” he inquired calmly. “Did we run outa gas?”
“Look!”
Half a dozen fingers pointed at the amputated wheel—he stared at it for a moment, and then looked upward as though he suspected that it had dropped from the sky.
“It came off,” someone explained.
He nodded.
“At first I din’ notice we’d stopped.”
A pause. Then, taking a long breath and straightening his shoulders, he remarked in a determined voice:
“Wonder’ff tell me where there’s a gas’line station?”
At least a dozen men, some of them a little better off than he was, explained to him that wheel and car were no longer joined by any physical bond.
“Back out,” he suggested after a moment. “Put her in reverse.”
“But the wheel’s off!”
He hesitated.
“No harm in trying,” he said.
The caterwauling horns had reached a crescendo and I turned away and cut across the lawn toward home. I glanced back once. A wafer of a moon was shining over Gatsby’s house, making the night fine as before, and surviving the laughter and the sound of his still glowing garden. A sudden emptiness seemed to flow now from the windows and the great doors, endowing with complete isolation the figure of the host, who stood on the porch, his hand up in a formal gesture of farewell.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over. The air was thick with the scent of jasmine and the faint hum of distant music, as though the party had merely paused to catch its breath. The moon hung low over the water, casting a silver sheen across the bay, and for a moment, I felt as though I had stepped into one of Gatsby’s dreams—those shimmering illusions he spun with such care and desperation.

A figure emerged from the shadows near the fountain, and I recognized Daisy’s delicate silhouette. She stood motionless, her white dress glowing in the moonlight, her face tilted toward the sky as if searching for something beyond the stars. I hesitated, unsure whether to approach or retreat, but before I could decide, she turned and saw me. Her expression was unreadable—somewhere between sorrow and relief.

“Nick,” she said softly, her voice barely more than a whisper. “I thought everyone had gone.”

“Not quite,” I replied, stepping closer. “It seems the night isn’t finished with us yet.”

She smiled faintly, but her eyes were distant. “It never is, is it? Not really.” She glanced back toward the house, where a single light still burned in an upstairs window. “Tom’s inside,” she added, though I hadn’t asked. “He’s waiting for me.”

I nodded, though I couldn’t fathom what words might pass between them now, after all that had happened. The weight of the evening pressed down on us—the shattered glass, the accusations, the terrible, unspoken truth lurking beneath every word. 

Daisy sighed and wrapped her arms around herself, as if suddenly cold. “Do you think it’s possible,” she began, then stopped, shaking her head. “No, never mind. It’s a foolish question.”

“What is it?” I asked, though I feared the answer.

She looked at me then, her eyes bright with unshed tears. “Do you think people can ever really change? Or are we all just… trapped?”

I thought of Gatsby, of his relentless hope, his belief in the green light across the bay. I thought of the way he had rewritten his past, as though sheer will could erase the years and make him anew. And yet, in the end, hadn’t he been exactly who he always was—a man chasing a dream that was always just out of reach?

“I don’t know,” I admitted. “But I think we keep trying anyway.”

Daisy’s laugh was brittle. “That’s the tragedy, isn’t it? We keep trying, even when we know it’s hopeless.”

A breeze stirred the leaves overhead, and for a moment, the music from some far-off party swelled, as if carried on the wind. It was a jazz tune, lively and careless, a stark contrast to the heaviness between us. 

“You should go inside,” I said gently. “It’s late.”

She nodded but made no move to leave. “Nick,” she said after a pause, “thank you. For everything. For being… you.”

I didn’t know what to say to that, so I simply bowed my head. When I looked up again, she was walking toward the house, her figure growing smaller and smaller until she disappeared through the door. 

I stood there for a long time, listening to the quiet lapping of the waves against the shore, the occasional cry of a night bird. The world felt vast and empty, as though the party had been a brief spark in the darkness, now extinguished. 

And then, from somewhere across the bay, a single firework burst in the sky—a final, fleeting burst of color before the night swallowed it whole. 

I turned and walked away, leaving Gatsby’s mansion behind me, its windows dark and its halls silent. The evening was over at last, but the echoes of it would linger, I knew, long after the sun rose on a new day.

events.title: Nick Reflects on Summer, New York, and Jordan's Dishonesty
detailed_summary: Reviewing his writing, Nick feels he might have overemphasized the significance of a few nights' events.
He clarifies they were just casual occurrences in a busy summer and, until later, less important than his personal affairs.
Nick describes his routine: working at Probity Trust in downtown New York.
He socialized casually with colleagues, having lunch at simple restaurants.
He had a brief relationship with a coworker from Jersey City, which ended passively when her brother showed disapproval and she went on vacation.
He usually dined alone at the Yale Club, finding it the day's gloomiest part, followed by studying investments in the library.
He enjoyed strolling through New York at night, liking its adventurous atmosphere and the constant motion of people and machines.
He fantasized about meeting romantic women on Fifth Avenue and entering their lives unnoticed.
Sometimes he felt a profound loneliness in the city twilight, recognizing it in other young clerks like himself.
The sight of taxis heading to the theatre district filled him with a sense of longing, imagining the shared excitement within.
He reconnected with Jordan Baker in midsummer.
Initially flattered by her fame as a golf champion, his feelings developed into a 'tender curiosity'.
He sensed her bored, haughty demeanor hid something.
During a house party, he discovered her dishonesty when she lied about leaving a borrowed car in the rain with the top down.
This triggered his memory of a rumored cheating incident at her first major golf tournament, where she allegedly moved her ball from a bad lie.
The scandal nearly reached the papers but faded after a caddy retracted his statement and another witness expressed doubt.
Nick realized Jordan avoided clever men because she preferred operating where dishonesty wouldn't be suspected.
He concluded she was 'incurably dishonest,' likely resorting to subterfuge from a young age to maintain her facade while satisfying her desires.
He reflects that female dishonesty doesn't provoke deep blame in him; he felt brief sorrow, then forgot.
At the same party, they discussed driving after she nearly hit a workman.
Nick called her a 'rotten driver,' urging more care.
Jordan claimed she was careful, relying on others to be careful and stay out of her way, stating 'It takes two to make an accident.'
When Nick posed meeting someone equally careless, she expressed hope she wouldn't, stating her dislike for careless people was why she liked Nick.
Her direct gaze and words shifted their relationship; Nick momentarily thought he loved her.
However, his cautious nature and internal rules prevented impulsive action.
He knew he needed to resolve a lingering romantic entanglement back home, characterized by weekly letters signed 'Love, Nick' and memories of the girl.
Nick concludes by asserting his own cardinal virtue: honesty, claiming to be one of the few honest people he knows.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Reading over what I have written so far, I see I have given the impression that the events of three nights several weeks apart were all that absorbed me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Everyone suspects himself of at least one of the cardinal virtues, and this is mine: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known.

events.text_segment:
Reading over what I have written so far, I see I have given the impression that the events of three nights several weeks apart were all that absorbed me. On the contrary, they were merely casual events in a crowded summer, and, until much later, they absorbed me infinitely less than my personal affairs.
Most of the time I worked. In the early morning the sun threw my shadow westward as I hurried down the white chasms of lower New York to the Probity Trust. I knew the other clerks and young bond-salesmen by their first names, and lunched with them in dark, crowded restaurants on little pig sausages and mashed potatoes and coffee. I even had a short affair with a girl who lived in Jersey City and worked in the accounting department, but her brother began throwing mean looks in my direction, so when she went on her vacation in July I let it blow quietly away.
I took dinner usually at the Yale Club—for some reason it was the gloomiest event of my day—and then I went upstairs to the library and studied investments and securities for a conscientious hour. There were generally a few rioters around, but they never came into the library, so it was a good place to work. After that, if the night was mellow, I strolled down Madison Avenue past the old Murray Hill Hotel, and over 33rd Street to the Pennsylvania Station.
I began to like New York, the racy, adventurous feel of it at night, and the satisfaction that the constant flicker of men and women and machines gives to the restless eye. I liked to walk up Fifth Avenue and pick out romantic women from the crowd and imagine that in a few minutes I was going to enter into their lives, and no one would ever know or disapprove. Sometimes, in my mind, I followed them to their apartments on the corners of hidden streets, and they turned and smiled back at me before they faded through a door into warm darkness. At the enchanted metropolitan twilight I felt a haunting loneliness sometimes, and felt it in others—poor young clerks who loitered in front of windows waiting until it was time for a solitary restaurant dinner—young clerks in the dusk, wasting the most poignant moments of night and life.
Again at eight o’clock, when the dark lanes of the Forties were lined five deep with throbbing taxicabs, bound for the theatre district, I felt a sinking in my heart. Forms leaned together in the taxis as they waited, and voices sang, and there was laughter from unheard jokes, and lighted cigarettes made unintelligible circles inside. Imagining that I, too, was hurrying towards gaiety and sharing their intimate excitement, I wished them well.
For a while I lost sight of Jordan Baker, and then in midsummer I found her again. At first I was flattered to go places with her, because she was a golf champion, and everyone knew her name. Then it was something more. I wasn’t actually in love, but I felt a sort of tender curiosity. The bored haughty face that she turned to the world concealed something—most affectations conceal something eventually, even though they don’t in the beginning—and one day I found what it was. When we were on a house-party together up in Warwick, she left a borrowed car out in the rain with the top down, and then lied about it—and suddenly I remembered the story about her that had eluded me that night at Daisy’s. At her first big golf tournament there was a row that nearly reached the newspapers—a suggestion that she had moved her ball from a bad lie in the semifinal round. The thing approached the proportions of a scandal—then died away. A caddy retracted his statement, and the only other witness admitted that he might have been mistaken. The incident and the name had remained together in my mind.
Jordan Baker instinctively avoided clever, shrewd men, and now I saw that this was because she felt safer on a plane where any divergence from a code would be thought impossible. She was incurably dishonest. She wasn’t able to endure being at a disadvantage and, given this unwillingness, I suppose she had begun dealing in subterfuges when she was very young in order to keep that cool, insolent smile turned to the world and yet satisfy the demands of her hard, jaunty body.
It made no difference to me. Dishonesty in a woman is a thing you never blame deeply—I was casually sorry, and then I forgot. It was on that same house-party that we had a curious conversation about driving a car. It started because she passed so close to some workmen that our fender flicked a button on one man’s coat.
“You’re a rotten driver,” I protested. “Either you ought to be more careful, or you oughtn’t to drive at all.”
“I am careful.”
“No, you’re not.”
“Well, other people are,” she said lightly.
“What’s that got to do with it?”
“They’ll keep out of my way,” she insisted. “It takes two to make an accident.”
“Suppose you met somebody just as careless as yourself.”
“I hope I never will,” she answered. “I hate careless people. That’s why I like you.”
Her grey, sun-strained eyes stared straight ahead, but she had deliberately shifted our relations, and for a moment I thought I loved her. But I am slow-thinking and full of interior rules that act as brakes on my desires, and I knew that first I had to get myself definitely out of that tangle back home. I’d been writing letters once a week and signing them: “Love, Nick,” and all I could think of was how, when that certain girl played tennis, a faint moustache of perspiration appeared on her upper lip. Nevertheless there was a vague understanding that had to be tactfully broken off before I was free.
Everyone suspects himself of at least one of the cardinal virtues, and this is mine: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known.
