On the contrary, they were merely casual events in a crowded summer, and, until much later, they absorbed me infinitely less than my personal affairs.  

Most of the time I worked. In the early morning the sun threw my shadow westward as I hurried down the white chasms of lower New York to the Probity Trust. I knew the other clerks and young bond-salesmen by their first names, and lunched with them in dark, crowded restaurants on little pig sausages and mashed potatoes and coffee. I even had a short affair with a girl who lived in Jersey City and worked in the accounting department, but her brother began throwing mean looks in my direction, so when she went on her vacation in July I let it blow quietly away.  

I took dinner usually at the Yale Club—for some reason it was the gloomiest event of my day—and then I went upstairs to the library and studied investments and securities for a conscientious hour. There were generally a few rioters around, but they never came into the library, so it was a good place to work. After that, if the night was mellow, I strolled down Madison Avenue past the old Murray Hill Hotel, and over Thirty-third Street to the Pennsylvania Station.  

I began to like New York, the racy, adventurous feel of it at night, and the satisfaction that the constant flicker of men and women and machines gives to the restless eye. I liked to walk up Fifth Avenue and pick out romantic women from the crowd and imagine that in a few minutes I was going to enter into their lives, and no one would ever know or disapprove. Sometimes, in my mind, I followed them to their apartments on the corners of hidden streets, and they turned and smiled back at me before they faded through a door into warm darkness. At the enchanted metropolitan twilight I felt a haunting loneliness sometimes, and felt it in others—poor young clerks who loitered in front of windows waiting until it was time for a solitary restaurant dinner—young clerks in the dusk, wasting the most poignant moments of night and life.  

Again at eight o’clock, when the dark lanes of the Forties were lined five deep with throbbing taxicabs, bound for the theatre district, I felt a sinking in my heart. Forms leaned together in the taxis as they waited, and voices sang, and there was laughter from unheard jokes, and lighted cigarettes outlined unintelligible gestures inside. Imagining that I, too, was hurrying toward gayety and sharing their intimate excitement, I wished them well.  

For a while I lost sight of Jordan Baker, and then in midsummer I found her again. At first I was flattered to go places with her, because she was a golf champion, and everyone knew her name. Then it was something more. I wasn’t actually in love, but I felt a sort of tender curiosity. The bored haughty face that she turned to the world concealed something—most affectations conceal something eventually, even though they don’t in the beginning—and one day I found what it was. When we were on a house-party together up in Warwick, she left a borrowed car out in the rain with the top down, and then lied about it—and suddenly I remembered the story about her that had eluded me that night at Daisy’s. At her first big golf tournament there was a row that nearly reached the newspapers—a suggestion that she had moved her ball from a bad lie in the semi-final round. The thing approached the proportions of a scandal—then died away. A caddy retracted his statement, and the only other witness admitted that he might have been mistaken. The incident and the name had remained together in my mind.  

Jordan Baker instinctively avoided clever, shrewd men, and now I saw that this was because she felt safer on a plane where any divergence from a code would be thought impossible. She was incurably dishonest. She wasn’t able to endure being at a disadvantage and, given this unwillingness, I suppose she had begun dealing in subterfuges when she was very young in order to keep that cool, insolent smile turned to the world and yet satisfy the demands of her hard, jaunty body.  

It made no difference to me. Dishonesty in a woman is a thing you never blame deeply—I was casually sorry, and then I forgot. It was on that same house party that we had a curious conversation about driving a car. It started because she passed so close to some workmen that our fender flicked a button on one man’s coat.  

‘You’re a rotten driver,’ I protested. ‘Either you ought to be more careful, or you oughtn’t to drive at all.’  

‘I am careful.’  

‘No, you’re not.’  

‘Well, other people are,’ she said lightly.  

‘What’s that got to do with it?’  

‘They’ll keep out of my way,’ she insisted. ‘It takes two to make an accident.’  

‘Suppose you met somebody just as careless as yourself.’  

‘I hope I never will,’ she answered. ‘I hate careless people. That’s why I like you.’  

Her gray, sun-strained eyes stared straight ahead, but she had deliberately shifted our relations, and for a moment I thought I loved her. But I am slow-thinking and full of interior rules that act as brakes on my desires, and I knew that first I had to get myself definitely out of that tangle back home. I’d been writing letters once a week and signing them: ‘Love, Nick,’ and all I could think of was how, when that certain girl played tennis, a faint mustache of perspiration appeared on her upper lip. Nevertheless there was a vague understanding that had to be tactfully broken off before I was free.  

Every one suspects himself of at least one of the cardinal virtues, and this is mine: I am one of the few honest people that I have ever known."*  

---

This passage captures Nick Carraway's reflections on his summer in New York, his observations of Jordan Baker, and his personal musings on honesty and relationships. Let me know if you'd like any clarifications or adjustments!

events.title: Cataloging Gatsby's Guests and Their Ignorance
characters: Various unnamed guests (mentioned by name in text)
detailed_summary: On Sundays, Gatsby's house refills with guests indulging in his luxurious offerings.
Guests circulate wild and uninformed rumors about their host, speculating he's a bootlegger or even a murderer related to German royalty and the devil.
Nick recalls documenting the names of summer party attendees on an old timetable.
He feels this list offers a more concrete picture of the attendees than simple generalizations.
The core observation is that these guests readily accepted Gatsby's hospitality while knowing virtually nothing about him.

Nick provides a detailed list of guests from East Egg, including families like the Chester Beckers, Leeches, Hornbeams, Willie Voltaires, and Blackbucks, along with individuals like Bunsen, Doctor Civet, the Ismays, Chrysties, Edgar Beaver, and Clarence Endive, sometimes noting their quirks or fates.

He continues with guests from farther on Long Island: the Cheadles, O. R. P. Schraeders, Stonewall Jackson Abrams, Fishguards, Ripley Snells (involved in an incident leading to jail), the Dancies, S. B. Whitebait, Maurice A. Flink, the Hammerheads, and Beluga the tobacco importer with his daughters.

Guests from West Egg are enumerated, many associated with the film industry: the Poles, Mulreadys, Cecil Roebuck, Cecil Schoen, Senator Gulick, Newton Orchid, Eckhaust, Clyde Cohen, Don S. Schwartz, Arthur McCarty, Catlips, Bembergs, and G. Earl Muldoon (whose brother committed murder).
Promoters and gamblers like Da Fontano, Ed Legros, James B. (“Rot-Gut”) Ferret, the De Jongs, and Ernest Lilly are listed; Ferret's presence in the garden signaled gambling losses.
A constant presence, Klipspringer, earned the nickname "the boarder."
Theatrical attendees included Gus Waize, Horace O’Donavan, Lester Myer, George Duckweed, and Francis Bull.

A lengthy list of New York guests follows: the Chromes, Backhyssons, Dennickers, Russel Betty, Corrigans, Kellehers, Dewars, Scullys, S. W. Belcher, Smirkes, the divorced Quinns, and Henry L. Palmetto (who died by suicide).
Benny McClenahan consistently arrived with four young women who, despite changing individuals, seemed identical and claimed dubious connections to wealthy families.

Nick adds more names from memory: Faustina O’Brien, the Baedeker girls, young Brewer (injured in the war), Mr. Albrucksburger and his fiancée Miss Haag, Ardita Fitz-Peters, Mr. P. Jewett, Miss Claudia Hip (with her supposed chauffeur), and an unnamed prince known as Duke.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All these people came to Gatsby’s house in the summer.

events.text_segment:
On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn.
“He’s a bootlegger,” said the young ladies, moving somewhere between his cocktails and his flowers. “One time he killed a man who had found out that he was nephew to Von Hindenburg and second cousin to the devil. Reach me a rose, honey, and pour me a last drop into that there crystal glass.”
Once I wrote down on the empty spaces of a timetable the names of those who came to Gatsby’s house that summer. It is an old timetable now, disintegrating at its folds, and headed “This schedule in effect July 5th, 1922.” But I can still read the grey names, and they will give you a better impression than my generalities of those who accepted Gatsby’s hospitality and paid him the subtle tribute of knowing nothing whatever about him.
From East Egg, then, came the Chester Beckers and the Leeches, and a man named Bunsen, whom I knew at Yale, and Doctor Webster Civet, who was drowned last summer up in Maine. And the Hornbeams and the Willie Voltaires, and a whole clan named Blackbuck, who always gathered in a corner and flipped up their noses like goats at whosoever came near. And the Ismays and the Chrysties (or rather Hubert Auerbach and Mr. Chrystie’s wife), and Edgar Beaver, whose hair, they say, turned cotton-white one winter afternoon for no good reason at all.
Clarence Endive was from East Egg, as I remember. He came only once, in white knickerbockers, and had a fight with a bum named Etty in the garden. From farther out on the Island came the Cheadles and the O. R. P. Schraeders, and the Stonewall Jackson Abrams of Georgia, and the Fishguards and the Ripley Snells. Snell was there three days before he went to the penitentiary, so drunk out on the gravel drive that Mrs. Ulysses Swett’s automobile ran over his right hand. The Dancies came, too, and S. B. Whitebait, who was well over sixty, and Maurice A. Flink, and the Hammerheads, and Beluga the tobacco importer, and Beluga’s girls.
From West Egg came the Poles and the Mulreadys and Cecil Roebuck and Cecil Schoen and Gulick the State senator and Newton Orchid, who controlled Films Par Excellence, and Eckhaust and Clyde Cohen and Don S. Schwartz (the son) and Arthur McCarty, all connected with the movies in one way or another. And the Catlips and the Bembergs and G. Earl Muldoon, brother to that Muldoon who afterward strangled his wife. Da Fontano the promoter came there, and Ed Legros and James B. (“Rot-Gut”) Ferret and the De Jongs and Ernest Lilly—they came to gamble, and when Ferret wandered into the garden it meant he was cleaned out and Associated Traction would have to fluctuate profitably next day.
A man named Klipspringer was there so often that he became known as “the boarder”—I doubt if he had any other home. Of theatrical people there were Gus Waize and Horace O’Donavan and Lester Myer and George Duckweed and Francis Bull. Also from New York were the Chromes and the Backhyssons and the Dennickers and Russel Betty and the Corrigans and the Kellehers and the Dewars and the Scullys and S. W. Belcher and the Smirkes and the young Quinns, divorced now, and Henry L. Palmetto, who killed himself by jumping in front of a subway train in Times Square.
Benny McClenahan arrived always with four girls. They were never quite the same ones in physical person, but they were so identical one with another that it inevitably seemed they had been there before. I have forgotten their names—Jaqueline, I think, or else Consuela, or Gloria or Judy or June, and their last names were either the melodious names of flowers and months or the sterner ones of the great American capitalists whose cousins, if pressed, they would confess themselves to be.
In addition to all these I can remember that Faustina O’Brien came there at least once and the Baedeker girls and young Brewer, who had his nose shot off in the war, and Mr. Albrucksburger and Miss Haag, his fiancée, and Ardita Fitz-Peters and Mr. P. Jewett, once head of the American Legion, and Miss Claudia Hip, with a man reputed to be her chauffeur, and a prince of something, whom we called Duke, and whose name, if I ever knew it, I have forgotten.
All these people came to Gatsby’s house in the summer.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
On Sunday morning while church bells rang in the villages alongshore, the world and its mistress returned to Gatsby’s house and twinkled hilariously on his lawn. The air was thick with the scent of freshly cut grass and the faint, lingering perfume of the previous night’s revelries. The sun, high and golden, cast long shadows across the manicured grounds, where guests—some familiar, some new—drifted like petals in a lazy summer breeze.  

Gatsby himself stood at the top of the marble steps, his white suit immaculate, his smile as dazzling as the champagne that flowed endlessly from silver fountains. He surveyed the scene with a quiet satisfaction, though his eyes—always restless—darted toward the shoreline, as if expecting someone who had yet to arrive.  

The orchestra, perched on a gilded platform beneath a striped awning, struck up a lively tune, and couples swayed together, their laughter mingling with the music. Women in fluttering pastel dresses and men in crisp linen suits moved through the crowd, their glasses clinking, their voices rising in animated conversation. The party, like all of Gatsby’s parties, was a spectacle of excess, a shimmering illusion of joy and carefree abandon.  

Yet beneath the glittering surface, there was something hollow, something fleeting. The guests, though they laughed and danced and drank with abandon, seemed to float through the scene like ghosts, their merriment as transient as the bubbles in their champagne. They spoke of Gatsby in hushed, speculative tones—*Who is he? Where does his money come from?*—but none truly knew him. To them, he was merely the enigmatic host, the man who opened his doors and let the world in, asking nothing in return but the privilege of their presence.  

And then, as if summoned by Gatsby’s silent longing, a sleek yellow car turned into the drive, its polished surface catching the sunlight. A hush fell over the crowd as all eyes turned toward the newcomer. The door opened, and out stepped Daisy Buchanan, her golden hair catching the light, her laughter like the chime of silver bells.  

Gatsby’s breath caught. For a moment, the world around him blurred, and there was nothing but her—the woman who had haunted his dreams, the green light at the end of his dock. He moved toward her as if drawn by an invisible thread, his heart pounding in his chest.  

“Daisy,” he murmured, his voice barely audible above the music.  

She turned, her eyes widening in surprise, then delight. “Jay,” she breathed, and in that single word, five years of longing seemed to dissolve.  

The guests, sensing the shift in the air, resumed their revelry, but Gatsby no longer noticed them. For him, the party had finally begun.  

And yet, even as he led Daisy through the gardens, showing her the splendor he had built for her, the specter of the past loomed between them. The green light across the bay, the years of separation, the life she had built without him—all of it hung in the air, unspoken but undeniable.  

The church bells had long since ceased their ringing, but in Gatsby’s heart, they tolled still—a quiet, persistent reminder that some dreams, no matter how dazzling, could never truly be recaptured.  

The party raged on, but for Gatsby, the world had narrowed to a single, fragile moment—one he would cling to, even as it slipped like sand through his fingers.

events.title: Gatsby's Invitation and Dubious Autobiography
detailed_summary: Late one July morning, Gatsby arrives unexpectedly at Nick's home in his striking car.
It's Gatsby's first visit to Nick, despite Nick attending his parties and using his amenities.
Gatsby invites Nick to lunch, proposing they travel to the city together.
Nick observes Gatsby's characteristic American restlessness beneath his formal demeanor, noting his constant fidgeting.
Gatsby notices Nick admiring his car and proudly encourages a closer look.
Nick describes the car's opulent appearance: cream-colored, nickel-adorned, monstrously long, and filled with compartments and mirrored windshields.
They set off for town, enclosed in the car's green leather interior.
Nick reflects on his disappointment from previous conversations, finding Gatsby had little to say, which had downgraded Nick's initial perception of him.
The car ride becomes uncomfortable as Gatsby grows agitated, leaving sentences unfinished and nervously tapping his knee.
Gatsby abruptly asks Nick's opinion of him.
Nick starts to offer a polite evasion, but Gatsby interrupts, wanting to share his life story to counteract rumors.
Gatsby asserts he will tell the "God's truth."
He claims descent from wealthy, deceased Midwestern parents and an Oxford education, citing it as a long-standing family tradition.
Nick perceives Gatsby's discomfort when mentioning Oxford, fueling Jordan Baker's earlier expressed doubt and making Nick question Gatsby's entire narrative, sensing something possibly sinister.
When asked about his Midwestern origins, Gatsby claims San Francisco.
He solemnly recounts inheriting substantial wealth after his family's demise.
Gatsby describes living like a young rajah across Europe (Paris, Venice, Rome), collecting jewels (especially rubies), hunting, painting privately, and trying to escape a past sorrow.
Nick finds the story incredibly clichéd, comparing it to a stereotypical fictional character, and struggles not to laugh.
Gatsby transitions to his war experience, portraying it as a relief where he courted death but seemed charmed.

He details his commission, leading a machine-gun battalion far ahead in the Argonne Forest, holding the position for two days against odds, and earning a promotion to Major and decorations from multiple Allied nations, including Montenegro.
Gatsby speaks fondly of Montenegro, displaying a smile that seems to encompass its history and struggles.
Nick's disbelief shifts towards fascination.
Gatsby produces a medal from Montenegro as evidence.
Nick examines the medal, noting its authentic appearance and inscription: "Orderi di Danilo, Montenegro, Nicolas Rex," and on the reverse, "Major Jay Gatsby, For Valour Extraordinary."
Gatsby then presents a photograph from his Oxford days at Trinity Quad, showing himself younger with several young men, one identified as the Earl of Doncaster.

events.text_segment:
At nine o’clock, one morning late in July, Gatsby’s gorgeous car lurched up the rocky drive to my door and gave out a burst of melody from its three-noted horn.
It was the first time he had called on me, though I had gone to two of his parties, mounted in his hydroplane, and, at his urgent invitation, made frequent use of his beach.
“Good morning, old sport. You’re having lunch with me today and I thought we’d ride up together.”
He was balancing himself on the dashboard of his car with that resourcefulness of movement that is so peculiarly American—that comes, I suppose, with the absence of lifting work in youth and, even more, with the formless grace of our nervous, sporadic games. This quality was continually breaking through his punctilious manner in the shape of restlessness. He was never quite still; there was always a tapping foot somewhere or the impatient opening and closing of a hand.
He saw me looking with admiration at his car.
“It’s pretty, isn’t it, old sport?” He jumped off to give me a better view. “Haven’t you ever seen it before?”
I’d seen it. Everybody had seen it. It was a rich cream colour, bright with nickel, swollen here and there in its monstrous length with triumphant hatboxes and supper-boxes and toolboxes, and terraced with a labyrinth of windshields that mirrored a dozen suns. Sitting down behind many layers of glass in a sort of green leather conservatory, we started to town.
I had talked with him perhaps half a dozen times in the past month and found, to my disappointment, that he had little to say. So my first impression, that he was a person of some undefined consequence, had gradually faded and he had become simply the proprietor of an elaborate roadhouse next door.
And then came that disconcerting ride. We hadn’t reached West Egg village before Gatsby began leaving his elegant sentences unfinished and slapping himself indecisively on the knee of his caramel-coloured suit.
“Look here, old sport,” he broke out surprisingly, “what’s your opinion of me, anyhow?”
A little overwhelmed, I began the generalized evasions which that question deserves.
“Well, I’m going to tell you something about my life,” he interrupted. “I don’t want you to get a wrong idea of me from all these stories you hear.”
So he was aware of the bizarre accusations that flavoured conversation in his halls.
“I’ll tell you God’s truth.” His right hand suddenly ordered divine retribution to stand by. “I am the son of some wealthy people in the Middle West—all dead now. I was brought up in America but educated at Oxford, because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. It is a family tradition.”
He looked at me sideways—and I knew why Jordan Baker had believed he was lying. He hurried the phrase “educated at Oxford,” or swallowed it, or choked on it, as though it had bothered him before. And with this doubt, his whole statement fell to pieces, and I wondered if there wasn’t something a little sinister about him, after all.
“What part of the Middle West?” I inquired casually.
“San Francisco.”
“I see.”
“My family all died and I came into a good deal of money.”
His voice was solemn, as if the memory of that sudden extinction of a clan still haunted him. For a moment I suspected that he was pulling my leg, but a glance at him convinced me otherwise.
“After that I lived like a young rajah in all the capitals of Europe—Paris, Venice, Rome—collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting a little, things for myself only, and trying to forget something very sad that had happened to me long ago.”
With an effort I managed to restrain my incredulous laughter. The very phrases were worn so threadbare that they evoked no image except that of a turbaned “character” leaking sawdust at every pore as he pursued a tiger through the Bois de Boulogne.
“Then came the war, old sport. It was a great relief, and I tried very hard to die, but I seemed to bear an enchanted life. I accepted a commission as first lieutenant when it began. In the Argonne Forest I took the remains of my machine-gun battalion so far forward that there was a half mile gap on either side of us where the infantry couldn’t advance. We stayed there two days and two nights, a hundred and thirty men with sixteen Lewis guns, and when the infantry came up at last they found the insignia of three German divisions among the piles of dead. I was promoted to be a major, and every Allied government gave me a decoration—even Montenegro, little Montenegro down on the Adriatic Sea!”
Little Montenegro! He lifted up the words and nodded at them—with his smile. The smile comprehended Montenegro’s troubled history and sympathized with the brave struggles of the Montenegrin people. It appreciated fully the chain of national circumstances which had elicited this tribute from Montenegro’s warm little heart. My incredulity was submerged in fascination now; it was like skimming hastily through a dozen magazines.
He reached in his pocket, and a piece of metal, slung on a ribbon, fell into my palm.
“That’s the one from Montenegro.”
To my astonishment, the thing had an authentic look. “Orderi di Danilo,” ran the circular legend, “Montenegro, Nicolas Rex.”
“Turn it.”
“Major Jay Gatsby,” I read, “For Valour Extraordinary.”
“Here’s another thing I always carry. A souvenir of Oxford days. It was taken in Trinity Quad—the man on my left is now the Earl of Doncaster.”
It was a photograph of half a dozen young men in blazers loafing in an archway through which were visible a host of spires. There was Gatsby, looking a little, not much, younger—with a cricket bat in his hand.

**text_segment**:  
*At nine o’clock, one morning late in July, Gatsby’s gorgeous car lurched up the rocky drive to my door and gave out a burst of melody from its three-noted horn. It was the first time he had called on me, though I had gone to two of his parties, mounted in his hydroplane, and, at his urgent invitation, made frequent use of his beach.*  

*“Good morning, old sport. You’re having lunch with me today and I thought we’d ride up together.”*  

*He was balancing himself on the dashboard of his car with that resourcefulness of movement that is so peculiarly American—that comes, I suppose, with the absence of lifting work or rigid sitting in youth and, even more, with the formless grace of our nervous, sporadic games. This quality was continually breaking through his punctilious manner in the shape of restlessness. He was never quite still; there was always a tapping foot somewhere or the impatient opening and closing of a hand.*  

*He saw me looking with admiration at his car.*  

*“It’s pretty, isn’t it, old sport?” He jumped off to give me a better view. “Haven’t you ever seen it before?”*  

*I’d seen it. Everybody had seen it. It was a rich cream color, bright with nickel, swollen here and there in its monstrous length with triumphant hat-boxes and supper-boxes and tool-boxes, and terraced with a labyrinth of windshields that mirrored a dozen suns. Sitting down behind many layers of glass in a sort of green leather conservatory, we started to town.*  

*I had talked with him perhaps half a dozen times in the past month and found, to my disappointment, that he had little to say. So my first impression, that he was a person of some undefined consequence, had gradually faded and he had become simply the proprietor of an elaborate roadhouse next door.*  

*And then came that disconcerting ride. We hadn’t reached West Egg village before Gatsby began leaving his elegant sentences unfinished and slapping himself indecisively on the knee of his caramel-colored suit.*  

*“Look here, old sport,” he broke out surprisingly, “what’s your opinion of me, anyhow?”*  

*A little overwhelmed, I began the generalized evasions which that question deserves.*  

*“Well, I’m going to tell you something about my life,” he interrupted. “I don’t want you to get a wrong idea of me from all these stories you hear.”*  

*So he was aware of the bizarre accusations that flavored conversation in his halls.*  

*“I’ll tell you God’s truth.” His right hand suddenly ordered divine retribution to stand by. “I am the son of some wealthy people in the Middle West—all dead now. I was brought up in America but educated at Oxford, because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. It is a family tradition.”*  

*He looked at me sideways—and I knew why Jordan Baker had believed he was lying. He hurried the phrase “educated at Oxford,” or swallowed it, or choked on it, as though it had bothered him before. And with this doubt, his whole statement fell to pieces, and I wondered if there wasn’t something a little sinister about him, after all.*  

*“What part of the Middle West?” I inquired casually.*  

*“San Francisco.”*  

*“I see.”*  

*“My family all died and I came into a good deal of money.”*  

*His voice was solemn, as if the memory of that sudden extinction of a clan still haunted him. For a moment I suspected that he was pulling my leg, but a glance at him convinced me otherwise.*  

*“After that I lived like a young rajah in all the capitals of Europe—Paris, Venice, Rome—collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting a little, things for myself only, and trying to forget something very sad that had happened to me long ago.”*  

*With an effort I managed to restrain my incredulous laughter. The very phrases were worn so threadbare that they evoked no image except that of a turbaned “character” leaking sawdust at every pore as he pursued a tiger through the Bois de Boulogne.*  

*“Then came the war, old sport. It was a great relief, and I tried very hard to die, but I seemed to bear an enchanted life. I accepted a commission as first lieutenant when it began. In the Argonne Forest I took two machine-gun detachments so far forward that there was a half mile gap on either side of us where the infantry couldn’t advance. We stayed there two days and two nights, a hundred and thirty men with sixteen Lewis guns, and when the infantry came up at last they found the insignia of three German divisions among the piles of dead. I was promoted to be a major, and every Allied government gave me a decoration—even Montenegro, little Montenegro down on the Adriatic Sea!”*  

*Little Montenegro! He lifted up the words and nodded at them—with his smile. The smile comprehended Montenegro’s troubled history and sympathized with the brave struggles of the Montenegrin people. It appreciated fully the chain of national circumstances which had elicited this tribute from Montenegro’s warm little heart. My incredulity was submerged in fascination now; it was like skimming hastily through a dozen magazines.*  

*He reached in his pocket, and a piece of metal, slung on a ribbon, fell into my palm.*  

*“That’s the one from Montenegro.”*  

*To my astonishment, the thing had an authentic look. “Orderi di Danilo,” ran the circular legend, “Montenegro, Nicolas Rex.”*  

*“Turn it.”*  

*“Major Jay Gatsby,” I read, “For Valour Extraordinary.”*  

*“Here’s another thing I always carry. A souvenir of Oxford days. It was taken in Trinity Quad—the man on my left is now the Earl of Doncaster.”*  

---

This passage captures the essence of Gatsby’s self-mythologizing and Nick’s shifting perceptions of him, blending opulence, fabrication, and a yearning for reinvention.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At nine o’clock, one morning late in July, Gatsby’s gorgeous car lurched up the rocky drive to my door and gave out a burst of melody from its three-noted horn. It was the first time he had called on me, though I had gone to two of his parties, mounted on his hydroplane, and, at his urgent invitation, made frequent use of his beach.  

“Good morning, old sport,” he said, stepping out of the car with that peculiar blend of formality and ease that was so distinctly his. “You’re coming over to lunch today, and I thought I’d ride over together.”  

I had not been aware of any such invitation, but Gatsby had a way of assuming things with such confidence that one hesitated to contradict him. His smile, bright and unwavering, suggested that the world operated exactly as he wished it to.  

“Well, I—” I began, but he was already opening the car door for me with a flourish.  

“No arguments, old sport. I’ve got something to show you.”  

The interior of the car was as lavish as its exterior—cream-colored leather, polished wood, and the faint scent of orchids lingering in the air. As we sped along the road, Gatsby handled the wheel with an easy mastery, though his eyes kept darting toward me as if he were eager to gauge my reaction to something.  

“You’ve been to my house,” he said suddenly.  

“Twice.”  

“But you haven’t seen it.”  

I frowned. “I’ve wandered through quite a bit of it.”  

“No, no,” he said impatiently. “You haven’t *seen* it.”  

I didn’t press the matter, sensing that he had some revelation in store. The landscape blurred past us, the heat of the day already pressing down, and I found myself wondering, not for the first time, what exactly Jay Gatsby wanted from me.  

When we arrived at his mansion, the usual army of servants was nowhere in sight. The house stood silent, its windows gleaming in the sunlight, as if holding its breath. Gatsby led me inside with an air of suppressed excitement.  

“This way,” he said, guiding me through the grand hall, past the ballroom where his parties roared into life, and up the staircase.  

At the top of the stairs, he paused before a door I had never noticed before—smaller, less ornate than the others, almost hidden in the shadows of the corridor. With a quick glance at me, as if to ensure I was watching, he turned the knob.  

The room beyond was a shock of simplicity in that palace of excess. A single bed, a plain desk, a bookshelf with a handful of well-worn volumes. On the wall hung a photograph—a young man in uniform, stiff and solemn, standing beside a girl whose smile was bright with promise.  

“That’s me,” Gatsby said quietly. “Five years ago.”  

I stepped closer. The man in the photo was undeniably him, though his face lacked the polished charm of the Gatsby I knew. The girl—her features were achingly familiar.  

“Daisy,” I murmured.  

He didn’t answer, but his silence was confirmation enough. For a long moment, we stood there, the past pressing in around us. Then, with a sudden movement, Gatsby crossed to the desk and opened a drawer.  

“I keep it here,” he said, lifting out a small, leather-bound book. “My ledger.”  

He handed it to me, and I flipped through the pages. Dates, sums, names—all meticulously recorded. But it wasn’t a financial ledger. It was a record of his life since that photo had been taken. Every step, every dollar, every connection, all leading back to one thing.  

“You see, old sport,” he said, his voice low and intense, “I wasn’t always like this. I made myself into what I am. For her.”  

I looked up at him, struck by the raw determination in his eyes. Here, in this hidden room, was the real Jay Gatsby—not the glittering host, not the mysterious millionaire, but a man who had built an empire out of sheer will, all for the sake of a dream.  

“And now,” he said, taking the book from me and carefully replacing it in the drawer, “she’s coming to lunch.”  

The words hung in the air between us, heavy with meaning. I understood then why he had brought me here—not just to witness his past, but to prepare me for what was to come.  

“You’ll help me, won’t you, old sport?”  

It wasn’t really a question. Gatsby had already decided how this story would go. All that remained was for the rest of us to play our parts.  

I nodded, and his smile returned, brighter than ever.  

“Good,” he said. “Then let’s not keep her waiting.”  

And with that, he led me back downstairs, where the servants had reappeared as if by magic, setting the table for lunch beneath the sparkling chandeliers. The past was tucked away again, the dream poised to take center stage.  

Somewhere beyond the bay, a green light flickered. Gatsby’s eyes strayed toward it for just a second before he turned to me, the perfect host once more.  

“Shall we?”

events.title: Gatsby's Mysterious Request and Journey to New York
detailed_summary: Temporarily swayed by the presented evidence (medal, photo), Nick visualizes Gatsby's romantic tales as potentially real.
Gatsby reveals the reason for sharing his past: he intends to ask Nick for a significant favor that day.
He explains his drifting lifestyle aims to forget past sadness and emphasizes wanting Nick to understand he isn't just 'some nobody'.
Gatsby states the details of the request will be conveyed by Jordan Baker when she meets Nick for tea later.
Nick feels more annoyed than intrigued by the secrecy and indirectness, briefly wishing he hadn't gotten involved with Gatsby.
Gatsby remains tight-lipped about the matter, adopting a more formal, correct demeanor as they approach New York City.
Their journey takes them past Port Roosevelt's ships, through a run-down area with old saloons, and across the desolate valley of ashes.
Nick catches a glimpse of Mrs. Wilson working vigorously at the garage pump as they speed past.
While driving rapidly through Astoria, a motorcycle policeman pulls them over.
Gatsby calmly displays a white card from his wallet to the officer.
The policeman immediately recognizes Gatsby, apologizes, tips his cap, and lets them proceed.
Gatsby explains the card is a courtesy from the police commissioner, whom he once assisted, and who sends him an annual Christmas card.
As they cross the Queensboro Bridge, Nick is captivated by the stunning view of the city skyline, seeing it as a symbol of endless possibility, mystery, and beauty.
The drive includes observations of city life: a funeral procession and a limousine carrying stylish black passengers driven by a white chauffeur.
These sights reinforce Nick's feeling that arriving in the city makes anything seem possible, including the existence of someone like Gatsby.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then it was all true.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Even Gatsby could happen, without any particular wonder.

events.text_segment:
Then it was all true. I saw the skins of tigers flaming in his palace on the Grand Canal; I saw him opening a chest of rubies to ease, with their crimson-lighted depths, the gnawings of his broken heart.
“I’m going to make a big request of you today,” he said, pocketing his souvenirs with satisfaction, “so I thought you ought to know something about me. I didn’t want you to think I was just some nobody. You see, I usually find myself among strangers because I drift here and there trying to forget the sad things that happened to me.” He hesitated. “You’ll hear about it this afternoon.”
“At lunch?”
“No, this afternoon. I happened to find out that you’re taking Miss Baker to tea.”
“Do you mean you’re in love with Miss Baker?”
“No, old sport, I’m not. But Miss Baker has kindly consented to speak to you about this matter.”
I hadn’t the faintest idea what “this matter” was, but I was more annoyed than interested. I hadn’t asked Jordan to tea in order to discuss Mr. Jay Gatsby. I was sure the request would be something utterly fantastic, and for a moment I was sorry I’d ever set foot upon his overpopulated lawn.
He wouldn’t say another word. His correctness grew on him as we neared the city. We passed Port Roosevelt, where there was a glimpse of red-belted oceangoing ships, and sped along a cobbled slum lined with the dark, undeserted saloons of the faded-gilt nineteen-hundreds. Then the valley of ashes opened out on both sides of us, and I had a glimpse of Mrs. Wilson straining at the garage pump with panting vitality as we went by.
With fenders spread like wings we scattered light through half Astoria—only half, for as we twisted among the pillars of the elevated I heard the familiar “jug-jug-spat!” of a motorcycle, and a frantic policeman rode alongside.
“All right, old sport,” called Gatsby. We slowed down. Taking a white card from his wallet, he waved it before the man’s eyes.
“Right you are,” agreed the policeman, tipping his cap. “Know you next time, Mr. Gatsby. Excuse me!”
“What was that?” I inquired. “The picture of Oxford?”
“I was able to do the commissioner a favour once, and he sends me a Christmas card every year.”
Over the great bridge, with the sunlight through the girders making a constant flicker upon the moving cars, with the city rising up across the river in white heaps and sugar lumps all built with a wish out of nonolfactory money. The city seen from the Queensboro Bridge is always the city seen for the first time, in its first wild promise of all the mystery and the beauty in the world.
A dead man passed us in a hearse heaped with blooms, followed by two carriages with drawn blinds, and by more cheerful carriages for friends. The friends looked out at us with the tragic eyes and short upper lips of southeastern Europe, and I was glad that the sight of Gatsby’s splendid car was included in their sombre holiday. As we crossed Blackwell’s Island a limousine passed us, driven by a white chauffeur, in which sat three modish negroes, two bucks and a girl. I laughed aloud as the yolks of their eyeballs rolled toward us in haughty rivalry.
“Anything can happen now that we’ve slid over this bridge,” I thought; “anything at all…”
Even Gatsby could happen, without any particular wonder.

A dead man passed us in a hearse heaped with blooms, followed by two carriages with drawn blinds, and by more cheerful carriages for friends. The friends looked out at us with the tragic eyes and short upper lips of southeastern Europe, and I was glad that the sight of Gatsby’s splendid car was included in their somber holiday. As we crossed Blackwell’s Island a limousine passed us, driven by a white chauffeur, in which sat three modish negroes, two bucks and a girl. I laughed aloud as the yolks of their eyeballs rolled toward us in haughty rivalry.  

‘Anything can happen now that we’ve slid over this bridge,’ I thought; ‘anything at all…’ Even Gatsby could happen, without any particular wonder."*  

---  

This passage aligns with the provided metadata, including the key moments of Gatsby revealing his past, the interaction with the policeman, the drive through the city, and Nick’s reflections on the possibilities of New York.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Then it was all true. I saw the tears on his face—there were tears on his face—and for the first time, I understood the depth of Gatsby’s longing, the sheer, unyielding force of his dream. It wasn’t just about Daisy, though she was the vessel that held it all. It was about something more, something vast and unnameable, the kind of hope that could only exist in a world where the past could be rewritten, where time itself could be bent to a man’s will.  

I had doubted him, of course. Who wouldn’t? The rumors, the whispers, the way he materialized out of nowhere with his grand parties and his phantom fortune—it was all too extravagant to be real. And yet, standing there in the soft glow of his mansion, watching him tremble with the weight of five years of waiting, I knew that none of it mattered. The money, the parties, the lies—they were just the scaffolding for something far more fragile, far more human.  

Gatsby believed in the green light. He believed in it with the kind of faith that moves mountains, that turns men into legends. And for a moment, as he stood there with Daisy in his arms, I almost believed it too. The past could be erased. The years could be undone. Love could conquer everything—even time itself.  

But then the clock on the mantelpiece slipped from his hands, and the sound of it shattering against the marble floor seemed to echo through the house like a gunshot. Gatsby flinched, and Daisy let out a small, startled laugh—the kind of laugh that hides fear. And in that instant, I saw the truth flicker across his face: the dream was already breaking.  

Because dreams, no matter how bright, how fiercely held, are still just dreams. And reality—cold, unyielding reality—always wins in the end.  

Later, when it was all over, when the blood had dried on the pavement and the reporters had come and gone, I found myself standing on Gatsby’s empty dock, staring across the water at the green light on Daisy’s pier. It was still there, still blinking faintly in the distance, but it didn’t mean anything anymore. Without Gatsby to reach for it, it was just another light on another shore.  

And that was the cruelest truth of all. The dream had never been about Daisy, not really. It had been about Gatsby—about the boy from North Dakota who had dared to imagine himself as something greater, something worthy of love. But in the end, the world didn’t care about dreams. It didn’t care about hope. It only cared about what was real.  

So yes, it was all true. The love, the longing, the tragedy—all of it. And yet, as I turned away from the water and walked back toward the house, I couldn’t help but wonder: if Gatsby had known how it would end, would he have done it all the same?  

I think he would have. Because some dreams are worth chasing, even if they destroy you in the end.

events.title: Lunch with Meyer Wolfshiem and Tales of the Underworld
detailed_summary: Nick meets Gatsby for lunch at a basement restaurant on Forty-second Street.
Gatsby introduces Nick to his companion, Mr. Meyer Wolfshiem.
Nick observes Wolfshiem's distinct appearance: small, flat-nosed, large-headed, with prominent nostril hair and small eyes.
Wolfshiem, after a perfunctory handshake, launches into an anecdote about forcefully silencing someone named Katspaugh, seemingly not directed at Nick.
Gatsby guides them to a table as Wolfshiem trails off into abstracted silence.
After ordering drinks, Wolfshiem comments on the restaurant, preferring the 'old Metropole' across the street for its associated memories.
He speaks nostalgically about the Metropole being filled with faces now gone, specifically mentioning friends lost forever.
Wolfshiem recounts in detail the night gangster Herman 'Rosy' Rosenthal was murdered at the Metropole.
He describes being at a table with Rosy when Rosy was called outside late at night.
Wolfshiem recalls warning Rosy not to go outside, urging him to make his potential enemies come inside instead.
Rosy disregarded the warning, asking the waiter not to clear his coffee before stepping onto the sidewalk where he was shot.
Nick interjects, recalling that four men were electrocuted for the crime.
Wolfshiem corrects him, stating five were executed (including Police Lieutenant Charles Becker), and then jarringly pivots, asking Nick if he is looking for a 'business gonnegtion'.
Gatsby quickly clarifies that Nick is merely a friend and not the intended party for such a discussion.
Wolfshiem apologizes for the misunderstanding.
As their meal (succulent hash) arrives, Wolfshiem eats with 'ferocious delicacy,' his eyes methodically scanning the entire restaurant, including the area behind their table.
Nick surmises that Wolfshiem's caution is intense, suggesting he might even check under the table if Nick wasn't there.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Roaring noon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think that, except for my presence, he would have taken one short glance beneath our own table.

events.text_segment:
Roaring noon. In a well-fanned Forty-second Street cellar I met Gatsby for lunch. Blinking away the brightness of the street outside, my eyes picked him out obscurely in the anteroom, talking to another man.
“Mr. Carraway, this is my friend Mr. Wolfshiem.”
A small, flat-nosed Jew raised his large head and regarded me with two fine growths of hair which luxuriated in either nostril. After a moment I discovered his tiny eyes in the half-darkness.
“—So I took one look at him,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, shaking my hand earnestly, “and what do you think I did?”
“What?” I inquired politely.
But evidently he was not addressing me, for he dropped my hand and covered Gatsby with his expressive nose.
“I handed the money to Katspaugh and I said: ‘All right, Katspaugh, don’t pay him a penny till he shuts his mouth.’ He shut it then and there.”
Gatsby took an arm of each of us and moved forward into the restaurant, whereupon Mr. Wolfshiem swallowed a new sentence he was starting and lapsed into a somnambulatory abstraction.
“Highballs?” asked the head waiter.
“This is a nice restaurant here,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, looking at the presbyterian nymphs on the ceiling. “But I like across the street better!”
“Yes, highballs,” agreed Gatsby, and then to Mr. Wolfshiem: “It’s too hot over there.”
“Hot and small—yes,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, “but full of memories.”
“What place is that?” I asked.
“The old Metropole.”
“The old Metropole,” brooded Mr. Wolfshiem gloomily. “Filled with faces dead and gone. Filled with friends gone now forever. I can’t forget so long as I live the night they shot Rosy Rosenthal there. It was six of us at the table, and Rosy had eat and drunk a lot all evening. When it was almost morning the waiter came up to him with a funny look and says somebody wants to speak to him outside. ‘All right,’ says Rosy, and begins to get up, and I pulled him down in his chair.
“ ‘Let the bastards come in here if they want you, Rosy, but don’t you, so help me, move outside this room.’
“It was four o’clock in the morning then, and if we’d of raised the blinds we’d of seen daylight.”
“Did he go?” I asked innocently.
“Sure he went.” Mr. Wolfshiem’s nose flashed at me indignantly. “He turned around in the door and says: ‘Don’t let that waiter take away my coffee!’ Then he went out on the sidewalk, and they shot him three times in his full belly and drove away.”
“Four of them were electrocuted,” I said, remembering.
“Five, with Becker.” His nostrils turned to me in an interested way. “I understand you’re looking for a business gonnegtion.”
The juxtaposition of these two remarks was startling. Gatsby answered for me:
“Oh, no,” he exclaimed, “this isn’t the man.”
“No?” Mr. Wolfshiem seemed disappointed.
“This is just a friend. I told you we’d talk about that some other time.”
“I beg your pardon,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, “I had a wrong man.”
A succulent hash arrived, and Mr. Wolfshiem, forgetting the more sentimental atmosphere of the old Metropole, began to eat with ferocious delicacy. His eyes, meanwhile, roved very slowly all around the room—he completed the arc by turning to inspect the people directly behind. I think that, except for my presence, he would have taken one short glance beneath our own table.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
**Roaring Noon**  

The sun hung high over West Egg, a merciless eye glaring down upon the manicured lawns and sprawling mansions that lined the shore. It was noon, but not the quiet, drowsy noon of the countryside—this was a roaring noon, alive with the hum of engines, the clink of glasses, and the restless energy of people who had too much money and too little to do.  

Jay Gatsby’s house was no exception. Even at this hour, the marble steps gleamed under the sun, and the windows of his mansion glittered like diamonds, reflecting the sky in a way that made the whole place seem unreal. Inside, the air was thick with the scent of imported flowers and the faint, lingering perfume of last night’s revelers. The servants moved like ghosts through the halls, clearing away the remnants of another endless party—crystal glasses smudged with lipstick, half-smoked cigarettes crushed into silver trays, silk scarves abandoned on gilded chairs.  

Gatsby himself stood on the terrace, his white suit immaculate against the blue of the Sound. He was staring across the water, as he so often did, toward the green light that flickered at the end of Daisy’s dock. Even in the harsh light of day, that light held its power over him, a siren call he could never resist.  

Nick Carraway, having wandered over in search of lunch or perhaps just to escape the oppressive solitude of his own bungalow, found him there.  

“You’re up early,” Nick remarked, though it was well past morning.  

Gatsby turned, his smile sudden and brilliant, as if he had been waiting for someone to interrupt his thoughts. “Early? No, old sport. The day’s hardly begun.”  

Nick didn’t argue. Time moved differently in Gatsby’s world—midnight could feel like dawn, and noon could roar like a party at full tilt.  

A servant appeared with a tray of cocktails, condensation dripping down the sides of the glasses. Gatsby took one without looking and handed another to Nick.  

“To the afternoon,” he said, raising his glass.  

Nick hesitated. “Isn’t it a bit early for this?”  

Gatsby’s smile didn’t waver. “It’s never too early for a dream.”  

And that was the heart of it, wasn’t it? Gatsby didn’t live in hours or minutes; he lived in dreams. Noon wasn’t just a time of day—it was another chance, another opportunity to reach for something just out of grasp.  

Somewhere in the distance, a car engine revved, loud and impatient. The sound seemed to stir the air, making the heat pulse like a living thing. Across the bay, Daisy’s house sat silent and still, its windows shuttered against the sun.  

Gatsby took a long sip of his drink, his gaze drifting back toward that tiny green light.  

The roaring noon stretched on, endless and electric, humming with the promise of something just about to happen.

events.title: Gatsby's Mysteries, Wolfshiem's Identity, and an Awkward Encounter
detailed_summary: Gatsby leans towards Nick, expressing concern that he might have angered him during the earlier car ride.
Nick resists Gatsby's smile, stating his dislike for mysteries and questioning the need for Jordan Baker's involvement in Gatsby's request.
Gatsby assures him it's nothing 'underhand,' praising Jordan's character as a sportswoman.
Gatsby abruptly checks his watch, excuses himself to make a phone call, and leaves Nick alone with Wolfshiem.
Wolfshiem observes Gatsby's departure, praising him as a 'fine fellow,' handsome, a 'perfect gentleman,' and an 'Oggsford man'.
Wolfshiem confirms he attended 'Oggsford College,' calling it one of the world's most famous.
He tells Nick he has known Gatsby for several years, since just after the war, and quickly recognized his 'fine breeding,' deeming him respectable enough to introduce to his mother and sister.
Wolfshiem notices Nick (or pretends to notice) looking at his cufflinks.
He reveals the cufflinks are made from human molars.
Wolfshiem then comments on Gatsby's supposed propriety concerning women, asserting he would never disrespect a friend's marriage.
Gatsby returns to the table.
Wolfshiem finishes his coffee abruptly and stands to leave, announcing his departure as belonging to an 'older generation' and not wanting to impose.
Gatsby offers a lukewarm suggestion for him to stay, but Wolfshiem gives a hand gesture like a blessing and leaves, his 'tragic nose' trembling.
Gatsby explains Wolfshiem's occasional sentimentality, describing him as a 'character around New York—a denizen of Broadway'.
When Nick asks Wolfshiem's profession (actor? dentist?), Gatsby hesitates before coolly revealing Wolfshiem is a gambler.
Gatsby adds the stunning information that Wolfshiem 'fixed the World's Series back in 1919.'
Nick is staggered, having considered the event a historical occurrence rather than the deliberate act of one man manipulating national faith.
Gatsby explains Wolfshiem simply 'saw the opportunity' and is too 'smart' to be caught.
Nick insists on paying the bill.
As the waiter brings change, Nick spots Tom Buchanan across the room and asks Gatsby to come meet him.
Tom approaches Nick eagerly, asking where he's been and mentioning Daisy's annoyance.
Nick introduces Gatsby to Tom.
They shake hands briefly; an unusual look of strain and embarrassment appears on Gatsby's face.
While Tom continues questioning Nick about being so far uptown, Nick turns to include Gatsby in the conversation, only to find he has disappeared.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I turned toward Mr. Gatsby, but he was no longer there.

events.text_segment:
“Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”
There was the smile again, but this time I held out against it.
“I don’t like mysteries,” I answered, “and I don’t understand why you won’t come out frankly and tell me what you want. Why has it all got to come through Miss Baker?”
“Oh, it’s nothing underhand,” he assured me. “Miss Baker’s a great sportswoman, you know, and she’d never do anything that wasn’t all right.”
Suddenly he looked at his watch, jumped up, and hurried from the room, leaving me with Mr. Wolfshiem at the table.
“He has to telephone,” said Mr. Wolfshiem, following him with his eyes. “Fine fellow, isn’t he? Handsome to look at and a perfect gentleman.”
“Yes.”
“He’s an Oggsford man.”
“Oh!”
“He went to Oggsford College in England. You know Oggsford College?”
“I’ve heard of it.”
“It’s one of the most famous colleges in the world.”
“Have you known Gatsby for a long time?” I inquired.
“Several years,” he answered in a gratified way. “I made the pleasure of his acquaintance just after the war. But I knew I had discovered a man of fine breeding after I talked with him an hour. I said to myself: ‘There’s the kind of man you’d like to take home and introduce to your mother and sister.’ ” He paused. “I see you’re looking at my cuff buttons.”
I hadn’t been looking at them, but I did now. They were composed of oddly familiar pieces of ivory.
“Finest specimens of human molars,” he informed me.
“Well!” I inspected them. “That’s a very interesting idea.”
“Yeah.” He flipped his sleeves up under his coat. “Yeah, Gatsby’s very careful about women. He would never so much as look at a friend’s wife.”
When the subject of this instinctive trust returned to the table and sat down Mr. Wolfshiem drank his coffee with a jerk and got to his feet.
“I have enjoyed my lunch,” he said, “and I’m going to run off from you two young men before I outstay my welcome.”
“Don’t hurry Meyer,” said Gatsby, without enthusiasm. Mr. Wolfshiem raised his hand in a sort of benediction.
“You’re very polite, but I belong to another generation,” he announced solemnly. “You sit here and discuss your sports and your young ladies and your—” He supplied an imaginary noun with another wave of his hand. “As for me, I am fifty years old, and I won’t impose myself on you any longer.”
As he shook hands and turned away his tragic nose was trembling. I wondered if I had said anything to offend him.
“He becomes very sentimental sometimes,” explained Gatsby. “This is one of his sentimental days. He’s quite a character around New York—a denizen of Broadway.”
“Who is he, anyhow, an actor?”
“No.”
“A dentist?”
“Meyer Wolfshiem? No, he’s a gambler.” Gatsby hesitated, then added, coolly: “He’s the man who fixed the World’s Series back in 1919.”
“Fixed the World’s Series?” I repeated.
The idea staggered me. I remembered, of course, that the World’s Series had been fixed in 1919, but if I had thought of it at all I would have thought of it as a thing that merely happened, the end of some inevitable chain. It never occurred to me that one man could start to play with the faith of fifty million people—with the single-mindedness of a burglar blowing a safe.
“How did he happen to do that?” I asked after a minute.
“He just saw the opportunity.”
“Why isn’t he in jail?”
“They can’t get him, old sport. He’s a smart man.”
I insisted on paying the check. As the waiter brought my change I caught sight of Tom Buchanan across the crowded room.
“Come along with me for a minute,” I said; “I’ve got to say hello to someone.”
When he saw us Tom jumped up and took half a dozen steps in our direction.
“Where’ve you been?” he demanded eagerly. “Daisy’s furious because you haven’t called up.”
“This is Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.”
They shook hands briefly, and a strained, unfamiliar look of embarrassment came over Gatsby’s face.
“How’ve you been, anyhow?” demanded Tom of me. “How’d you happen to come up this far to eat?”
“I’ve been having lunch with Mr. Gatsby.”
I turned toward Mr. Gatsby, but he was no longer there.

“Have you known Gatsby for a long time?” I inquired.  

“Several years,” he answered in a gratified way. “I made the pleasure of his acquaintance just after the war. But I knew I had discovered a man of fine breeding after I talked with him an hour. I said to myself: ‘There’s the kind of man you’d like to take home and introduce to your mother and sister.’” He paused. “I see you’re looking at my cuff buttons.”  

I hadn’t been looking at them, but I did now. They were composed of oddly familiar pieces of ivory.  

“Finest specimens of human molars,” he informed me.  

“Well!” I said. “That’s a very interesting idea.”  

“Yeah.” He flipped his sleeves up under his coat. “Yeah, Gatsby’s very careful about women. He would never so much as look at a friend’s wife.”  

When the subject of this instinctive trust returned to the table and sat down Mr. Wolfshiem drank his coffee with a jerk and got to his feet.  

“I have enjoyed my lunch,” he said, “and I’m going to run off from you two young men before I outstay my welcome.”  

“Don’t hurry, Meyer,” said Gatsby, without enthusiasm. Mr. Wolfshiem raised his hand in a sort of benediction.  

“You’re very polite, but I belong to another generation,” he announced solemnly. “You sit here and discuss your sports and your young ladies and your—” He supplied an imaginary noun with another wave of his hand. “As for me, I am fifty years old, and I won’t impose myself on you any longer.”  

As he shook hands and turned away his tragic nose was trembling. I imagined that I saw him wink at Gatsby, but I could have been mistaken.  

“He becomes very sentimental sometimes,” explained Gatsby. “This is one of his sentimental days. He’s quite a character around New York—a denizen of Broadway.”  

“Who is he, anyhow, an actor?”  

“No.”  

“A dentist?”  

“Meyer Wolfshiem? No, he’s a gambler.” Gatsby hesitated, then added coolly: “He’s the man who fixed the World’s Series back in 1919.”  

“Fixed the World’s Series?” I repeated.  

The idea staggered me. I remembered, of course, that the World’s Series had been fixed in 1919, but if I had thought of it at all I would have thought of it as a thing that merely *happened*, the end of some inevitable chain. It never occurred to me that one man could start to play with the faith of fifty million people—with the single-mindedness of a burglar blowing a safe.  

“How did he happen to do that?” I asked after a minute.  

“He just saw the opportunity.”  

“Why isn’t he in jail?”  

“They can’t get him, old sport. He’s a smart man.”  

I insisted on paying the check. As the waiter brought my change I caught sight of Tom Buchanan across the crowded room.  

“Come along with me for a minute,” I said; “I’ve got to say hello to someone.”  

When he saw us Tom jumped up and took half a dozen steps in our direction.  

“Where’ve you been?” he demanded eagerly. “Daisy’s furious because you haven’t called up.”  

“This is Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.”  

They shook hands briefly, and a strained, unfamiliar look of embarrassment came over Gatsby’s face.  

“How’ve you been, anyhow?” demanded Tom of me. “How’d you happen to come up this far to eat?”  

“I’ve been having lunch with Mr. Gatsby.”  

I turned toward Mr. Gatsby, but he was no longer there.  

---

This passage is from *The Great Gatsby* by F. Scott Fitzgerald, Chapter IV.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Look here, old sport,” said Gatsby, leaning toward me, “I’m afraid I made you a little angry this morning in the car.”  

There was something almost boyish in his tone, a vulnerability that caught me off guard. The afternoon sun streamed through the high windows of his library, casting long shadows across the rows of untouched books. I hadn’t been angry, not really—just unsettled, perhaps, by the way he had spoken so casually about Daisy, as though the past five years had been nothing more than an inconvenient pause in their story.  

“Not at all,” I lied, swirling the whiskey in my glass. The ice had long since melted, leaving the drink lukewarm and unappealing.  

Gatsby’s eyes flickered with something unreadable—doubt, maybe, or the faintest trace of desperation. He straightened slightly, adjusting the crisp cuff of his shirt. “You see, I don’t want you to think I’m taking any of this lightly. It’s just that when a man has waited as long as I have, he starts to see things differently.”  

I nodded, though I wasn’t sure I understood. Gatsby’s world was one of grand gestures and unshakable faith, a place where dreams were not just possible but inevitable. Mine was smaller, quieter, bound by the practicalities of life.  

“She’s different now,” I said carefully, not wanting to wound him but unable to let the illusion stand unchallenged. “People change, Gatsby.”  

For a moment, he looked almost stricken. Then the mask slipped back into place, that dazzling smile that had charmed half of Long Island. “Of course,” he said smoothly. “But some things—some feelings—they don’t change. Not really.”  

I wanted to argue, to tell him that time had a way of eroding even the strongest emotions, that Daisy was not the girl he remembered. But the intensity in his gaze stopped me. He believed in her, in them, with a fervor that bordered on religious. Who was I to dismantle that?  

Instead, I took another sip of my drink and changed the subject. “You’ve got quite a collection here,” I said, gesturing to the shelves. “Do you read them?”  

Gatsby laughed, a rich, easy sound. “I like to think they read themselves, old sport. The right books have a way of finding their readers, don’t you think?”  

It was the kind of answer that revealed nothing and everything at once. I wondered if he had ever actually opened one of those volumes or if they were just another part of the elaborate set he had constructed for himself.  

The silence stretched between us, comfortable but weighted. Outside, the sound of a motorboat cut across the bay, a distant hum that faded as quickly as it had come.  

“Nick,” he said suddenly, his voice low and earnest, “you’ll help me, won’t you? With Daisy, I mean.”  

I hesitated. There was something tragic in the request, a plea from a man who had built his life around a single, unattainable ideal. And yet, I couldn’t refuse him. There was a magnetism to Gatsby, a pull that made you want to believe in his dreams, even if only for a moment.  

“Of course,” I said.  

His face lit up, and for the first time that afternoon, he looked truly at ease. “I knew I could count on you, old sport. You’re the only real friend I’ve got.”  

The words should have been flattering, but they left me with a strange sense of unease. Friendship with Gatsby was a slippery thing, built on half-truths and unspoken expectations. Still, I smiled and raised my glass in a silent toast.  

As the afternoon wore on, the conversation drifted to lighter topics—polo matches, the latest gossip from the city, the absurdity of Tom’s latest rant about the “rising tide of colored empires.” But beneath it all, I couldn’t shake the feeling that I had just agreed to something far more complicated than I realized.  

Gatsby’s world was one of shimmering illusions, where the line between reality and fantasy blurred with every passing moment. And now, whether I liked it or not, I was a part of it.

events.title: Jordan Recounts Daisy and Gatsby's Early Romance and Her Pre-Wedding Crisis
detailed_summary: The narrative shifts to Jordan Baker telling Nick a story later that afternoon in the Plaza Hotel's tea-garden.
Jordan recalls walking in Louisville in October 1917, wearing distinctive English shoes.
She describes passing Daisy Fay's house; Daisy, then eighteen and Louisville's most popular girl, constantly received calls from officers stationed at Camp Taylor.
Jordan recounts seeing Daisy sitting in her white roadster beside the curb with a lieutenant Jordan hadn't seen before.
The couple was so intensely focused on each other they didn't notice Jordan until she was very close.
Daisy called Jordan over, flattering her by wanting to speak to her.
Daisy asked Jordan to relay a message that she couldn't make it to the Red Cross that day.
Jordan distinctly remembers the way the lieutenant looked at Daisy while she spoke – a look of adoration she found romantic and memorable.
Jordan reveals the lieutenant's name was Jay Gatsby, and she didn't recognize him again for over four years, not even initially after meeting him on Long Island.
Jordan explains that by the following year (1918), she was occupied with her own social life and golf tournaments and saw less of Daisy.
Rumors circulated about Daisy's mother finding her packing to go to New York to bid farewell to a soldier heading overseas; she was stopped and estranged from her family for weeks.
After that incident, Daisy stopped socializing with soldiers and only associated with local young men unfit for military service.
By the autumn of 1919, Daisy was cheerful again, had her debutante presentation after the armistice, and was reportedly engaged by February.
In June, she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago in an exceptionally grand wedding for Louisville.
Tom arrived with a large entourage, rented an entire hotel floor, and gave Daisy a pearl necklace valued at $350,000 the day before the ceremony.
Jordan, serving as a bridesmaid, entered Daisy's room thirty minutes before the bridal dinner.
She found Daisy lying on her bed, beautifully dressed but extremely drunk, holding a bottle of Sauterne and a letter.
Daisy, admitting she'd never drunk before, urged Jordan to congratulate her.
Scared, Jordan asked what was wrong.
Daisy retrieved the pearl necklace from a wastebasket, telling Jordan to return it to its owner and declare that 'Daisy's change' her mind.'
Daisy then broke down, crying hysterically.
Jordan fetched Daisy's mother's maid; they locked the door and forced Daisy into a cold bath.
Daisy clung to the letter, taking it into the tub until it dissolved into a wet pulp, finally allowing Jordan to place the remains in the soap dish.
Daisy spoke no further about the incident.
They revived her with smelling salts, applied ice, dressed her, and half an hour later, she emerged composed with the pearls around her neck.
The following day at 5 PM, she married Tom Buchanan calmly and left for a three-month honeymoon in the South Seas.

events.text_segment:
One October day in nineteen-seventeen—
(said Jordan Baker that afternoon, sitting up very straight on a straight chair in the tea-garden at the Plaza Hotel)
—I was walking along from one place to another, half on the sidewalks and half on the lawns. I was happier on the lawns because I had on shoes from England with rubber knobs on the soles that bit into the soft ground. I had on a new plaid skirt also that blew a little in the wind, and whenever this happened the red, white, and blue banners in front of all the houses stretched out stiff and said tut-tut-tut-tut, in a disapproving way.
The largest of the banners and the largest of the lawns belonged to Daisy Fay’s house. She was just eighteen, two years older than me, and by far the most popular of all the young girls in Louisville. She dressed in white, and had a little white roadster, and all day long the telephone rang in her house and excited young officers from Camp Taylor demanded the privilege of monopolizing her that night. “Anyways, for an hour!”
When I came opposite her house that morning her white roadster was beside the kerb, and she was sitting in it with a lieutenant I had never seen before. They were so engrossed in each other that she didn’t see me until I was five feet away.
“Hello, Jordan,” she called unexpectedly. “Please come here.”
I was flattered that she wanted to speak to me, because of all the older girls I admired her most. She asked me if I was going to the Red Cross to make bandages. I was. Well, then, would I tell them that she couldn’t come that day? The officer looked at Daisy while she was speaking, in a way that every young girl wants to be looked at sometime, and because it seemed romantic to me I have remembered the incident ever since. His name was Jay Gatsby, and I didn’t lay eyes on him again for over four years—even after I’d met him on Long Island I didn’t realize it was the same man.
That was nineteen-seventeen. By the next year I had a few beaux myself, and I began to play in tournaments, so I didn’t see Daisy very often. She went with a slightly older crowd—when she went with anyone at all. Wild rumours were circulating about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag one winter night to go to New York and say goodbye to a soldier who was going overseas. She was effectually prevented, but she wasn’t on speaking terms with her family for several weeks. After that she didn’t play around with the soldiers any more, but only with a few flat-footed, shortsighted young men in town, who couldn’t get into the army at all.
By the next autumn she was gay again, gay as ever. She had a début after the armistice, and in February she was presumably engaged to a man from New Orleans. In June she married Tom Buchanan of Chicago, with more pomp and circumstance than Louisville ever knew before. He came down with a hundred people in four private cars, and hired a whole floor of the Muhlbach Hotel, and the day before the wedding he gave her a string of pearls valued at three hundred and fifty thousand dollars.
I was a bridesmaid. I came into her room half an hour before the bridal dinner, and found her lying on her bed as lovely as the June night in her flowered dress—and as drunk as a monkey. She had a bottle of Sauterne in one hand and a letter in the other.
“ ’Gratulate me,” she muttered. “Never had a drink before, but oh how I do enjoy it.”
“What’s the matter, Daisy?”
I was scared, I can tell you; I’d never seen a girl like that before.
“Here, dearies.” She groped around in a wastebasket she had with her on the bed and pulled out the string of pearls. “Take ’em downstairs and give ’em back to whoever they belong to. Tell ’em all Daisy’s change’ her mine. Say: ‘Daisy’s change’ her mine!’ ”
She began to cry—she cried and cried. I rushed out and found her mother’s maid, and we locked the door and got her into a cold bath. She wouldn’t let go of the letter. She took it into the tub with her and squeezed it up in a wet ball, and only let me leave it in the soap-dish when she saw that it was coming to pieces like snow.
But she didn’t say another word. We gave her spirits of ammonia and put ice on her forehead and hooked her back into her dress, and half an hour later, when we walked out of the room, the pearls were around her neck and the incident was over. Next day at five o’clock she married Tom Buchanan without so much as a shiver, and started off on a three months’ trip to the South Seas.
