LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees, its windows glowing like golden eyes in the night. The long, white façade loomed larger as we approached, its grandeur both inviting and imposing. Tom Buchanan’s voice, loud and brash, carried across the lawn as he called out to us, his figure silhouetted against the light spilling from the open door.  

Nick and I stepped onto the wide veranda, the scent of honeysuckle thick in the humid air. The house was alive with movement—servants gliding silently through the halls, the clink of ice in glasses, the murmur of voices from the drawing room. Daisy’s laughter, light and musical, drifted toward us, followed by the deeper tones of Jordan Baker’s dry wit.  

Tom ushered us inside, his hand heavy on my shoulder. “Gatsby, old sport, you’ve got to try this bourbon. Imported just last week.” His voice boomed with the confidence of a man who had never wanted for anything. The room was opulent, filled with overstuffed furniture and delicate china, every surface polished to a high sheen. A grand piano stood in the corner, untouched, its keys gleaming under the chandelier’s glow.  

Daisy appeared in the doorway, her dress shimmering like moonlight on water. “Jay,” she breathed, her smile both warm and distant, as if she were greeting a ghost. There was something fragile in her expression, a flicker of uncertainty beneath the practiced charm.  

Jordan lounged on a sofa, her sharp eyes taking in the scene with amusement. “You’re late,” she remarked, swirling her drink. “We’ve already dissected half of New York’s scandals without you.”  

The evening unfolded in a haze of cigarette smoke and murmured conversations. Tom dominated the room, his opinions loud and unchallenged, while Daisy flitted between guests, her laughter never quite reaching her eyes. I watched her, the way her fingers trembled slightly around her glass, the way she avoided looking at me for too long.  

At one point, I found myself alone with her on the terrace. The night air was cooler there, the sounds of the party muffled. She turned to me, her face half in shadow. “Do you ever think about Louisville, Jay?” she asked softly.  

The question caught me off guard. Louisville—the city where we had met, where everything had been simple and full of promise. “All the time,” I admitted.  

She sighed, her breath stirring the tendrils of hair at her temples. “Sometimes I wonder what would have happened if—”  

“Daisy!” Tom’s voice cut through the moment like a knife. He stood in the doorway, his expression unreadable. “Jordan’s about to tell that story about the tennis match. You’ll want to hear it.”  

Daisy’s smile returned, bright and automatic. “Of course,” she said, slipping past me without another word.  

I stayed on the terrace a moment longer, listening to the rustle of the trees, the distant hum of the city. The Buchanans’ house, with its polished surfaces and carefully arranged lives, felt like a stage set—beautiful but hollow. And yet, I couldn’t look away.  

When I rejoined the party, Tom was pouring another drink, his face flushed with triumph. Jordan was smirking at something Daisy had said, and Nick watched it all with quiet detachment. The night stretched on, filled with laughter and empty words, the kind of evening that left you feeling both exhausted and strangely unsatisfied.  

As we finally said our goodbyes, Daisy touched my arm lightly. “You’ll come again, won’t you, Jay?”  

I nodded, though I wasn’t sure what I was agreeing to. The drive back to West Egg was quiet, the road dark and winding. Nick was lost in thought beside me, and I couldn’t help but wonder if he, too, felt the weight of the evening—the unspoken tensions, the things left unsaid.  

The green light at the end of Daisy’s dock flickered in the distance as we crossed the bridge, a faint, persistent glow against the black water. I thought of her question about Louisville, the unfinished sentence hanging between us.  

Some dreams, it seemed, were never meant to be caught.

events.title: Nick's Anxious Vigil and Gatsby's Despair
detailed_summary: Nick spends a sleepless night disturbed by a foghorn and troubling thoughts, feeling an urgent need to warn Gatsby.
He goes to Gatsby's house at dawn, finding the door open and Gatsby inside, looking exhausted and dejected.
Gatsby reports that Daisy came to the window briefly during the night but then turned off the light, offering no resolution.
Nick observes the immense, dusty, and unused state of Gatsby's mansion as they search for cigarettes, highlighting its emptiness.
They sit smoking by the open windows.
Nick advises Gatsby to leave town immediately, suggesting Atlantic City or Montreal, fearing Gatsby's car will be traced back to the accident.
Gatsby refuses, stating he cannot leave until he knows Daisy's decision, clinging to a final hope.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

events.text_segment:
I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. Toward dawn I heard a taxi go up Gatsby’s drive, and immediately I jumped out of bed and began to dress—I felt that I had something to tell him, something to warn him about, and morning would be too late.
Crossing his lawn, I saw that his front door was still open and he was leaning against a table in the hall, heavy with dejection or sleep.
“Nothing happened,” he said wanly. “I waited, and about four o’clock she came to the window and stood there for a minute and then turned out the light.”
His house had never seemed so enormous to me as it did that night when we hunted through the great rooms for cigarettes. We pushed aside curtains that were like pavilions, and felt over innumerable feet of dark wall for electric light switches—once I tumbled with a sort of splash upon the keys of a ghostly piano. There was an inexplicable amount of dust everywhere, and the rooms were musty, as though they hadn’t been aired for many days. I found the humidor on an unfamiliar table, with two stale, dry cigarettes inside. Throwing open the French windows of the drawing-room, we sat smoking out into the darkness.
“You ought to go away,” I said. “It’s pretty certain they’ll trace your car.”
“Go away now, old sport?”
“Go to Atlantic City for a week, or up to Montreal.”
He wouldn’t consider it. He couldn’t possibly leave Daisy until he knew what she was going to do. He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. The events of the evening played over and over in my mind like a broken record—Gatsby’s desperate eyes, Daisy’s trembling voice, and Tom’s cold, brutal triumph. The air in my room felt thick, suffocating, as though the weight of the night had settled into the very walls.  

Outside, the fog pressed against the windows, muffling the world beyond. The horn’s mournful cry seemed to echo the hollowness inside me, a sound that belonged neither to land nor sea but to some limbo where lost things wandered. I thought of Gatsby standing alone in his mansion, waiting for a call that would never come, and the image filled me with a dull, aching dread.  

When dawn finally crept in, gray and reluctant, I rose and dressed mechanically. The house was silent, but the echoes of the night’s chaos still hummed beneath the surface. I stepped outside, hoping the morning air might clear my head, but the fog clung stubbornly, obscuring everything beyond a few feet. It was as if the world itself had conspired to keep the truth hidden, to let the wreckage of our lives drift unseen into oblivion.  

And then, as I stood there, the telephone rang inside—a sharp, jarring sound that shattered the stillness. I knew, even before I answered, that nothing would ever be the same again.

events.title: Gatsby Recounts His Early Romance with Daisy
detailed_summary: Gatsby, feeling his persona shattered after the confrontation with Tom, confides in Nick about his past, specifically focusing on Daisy.
He describes Daisy as the first 'nice' girl he had ever known, encountered while he was an officer at Camp Taylor.
He was captivated by her beauty, her magnificent house, and the aura of wealth, mystery, and romance surrounding her life.
He notes the casualness with which she inhabited this world, so different from his own experience.
Gatsby found Daisy more desirable because many other men had loved her, feeling their emotional presence in her house.
He acknowledges his presence in her world was accidental; as a penniless man without a past, his uniform provided temporary cover.
He pursued Daisy intensely, taking what he could, aware he had no 'right' to her.
He admits he misled Daisy, letting her believe he belonged to her social stratum and could provide for her, though he couldn't.
Despite intending a temporary affair, Gatsby found himself deeply committed, as if following a 'grail'.
He realized the profound impact Daisy, as an extraordinary 'nice' girl, had on him, leaving him feeling empty yet married to her when she returned to her wealthy life.
He recalls their reunion two days later, feeling breathless and betrayed, yet overwhelmingly aware of the allure of her youth, wealth, and voice, which seemed to imprison and preserve her.
Gatsby confesses his surprise at falling in love and how his ambitions seemed less important than sharing his plans with Daisy.
He describes their last, tranquil afternoon together before he went to war, emphasizing their silent, profound connection and intimacy.

events.text_segment:
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. I think that he would have acknowledged anything now, without reserve, but he wanted to talk about Daisy.
She was the first “nice” girl he had ever known. In various unrevealed capacities he had come in contact with such people, but always with indiscernible barbed wire between. He found her excitingly desirable. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. It amazed him—he had never been in such a beautiful house before. But what gave it an air of breathless intensity, was that Daisy lived there—it was as casual a thing to her as his tent out at camp was to him. There was a ripe mystery about it, a hint of bedrooms upstairs more beautiful and cool than other bedrooms, of gay and radiant activities taking place through its corridors, and of romances that were not musty and laid away already in lavender but fresh and breathing and redolent of this year’s shining motorcars and of dances whose flowers were scarcely withered. It excited him, too, that many men had already loved Daisy—it increased her value in his eyes. He felt their presence all about the house, pervading the air with the shades and echoes of still vibrant emotions.
But he knew that he was in Daisy’s house by a colossal accident. However glorious might be his future as Jay Gatsby, he was at present a penniless young man without a past, and at any moment the invisible cloak of his uniform might slip from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took what he could get, ravenously and unscrupulously—eventually he took Daisy one still October night, took her because he had no real right to touch her hand.
He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretences. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same strata as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.
But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.
When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.
“I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”
On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised. They had never been closer in their month of love, nor communicated more profoundly one with another, than when she brushed silent lips against his coat’s shoulder or when he touched the end of her fingers, gently, as though she were asleep.

Here is the corresponding text segment from *The Great Gatsby* by F. Scott Fitzgerald:

---

**text_segment**:  
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. I suppose he’d had the name ready for a long time, even then. His parents were shiftless and unsuccessful farm people—his imagination had never really accepted them as his parents at all. The truth was that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, sprang from his Platonic conception of himself. He was a son of God—a phrase which, if it means anything, means just that—and he must be about His Father’s business, the service of a vast, vulgar, and meretricious beauty. So he invented just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy would be likely to invent, and to this conception he was faithful to the end.  

He told me all this very much later, but I’ve put it down here with the idea of exploding those first wild rumors about his antecedents, which weren’t even faintly true. Moreover he told it to me at a time of confusion, when I had reached the point of believing everything and nothing about him. So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.  

It was a chance encounter, he told me. He had gone over to Camp Taylor, near Louisville, in his officer’s uniform, and one afternoon he had met Daisy Fay, the first “nice” girl he had ever known. He had taken her because he had no real right to touch her hand. He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretenses. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same stratum as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.  

But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.  

When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.  

“I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, ‘way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”  

On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised.  

---

This passage captures Gatsby’s confession to Nick about his past with Daisy, his illusions, and the emotional weight of their relationship. It aligns with the metadata provided, including the key themes of Gatsby’s self-invention, his longing for Daisy, and the contrast between their worlds.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
Here is the fully refined and accurate recreation of the original passage from *The Great Gatsby*, incorporating all the missing elements and correcting structural and tonal issues:

---

**text_segment**:  
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. He was willing to say anything now, his reserve toward me broken down, and so I learned more of his past than I had ever known before.  

She was the first “nice” girl he had ever known. In various unrevealed capacities he had come in contact with such people before, but always with indiscernible barbed wire between. He found her excitingly desirable. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. It amazed him—he had never been in such a beautiful house before, but what gave it an air of breathless intensity was that Daisy lived there—it was as casual a thing to her as his tent out at camp was to him. There was a ripe mystery about it, a hint of bedrooms upstairs more beautiful and cool than other bedrooms, of gay and radiant activities taking place through its corridors, and of romances that were not musty and laid away already in lavender but fresh and breathing and redolent of this year’s shining motor-cars and of dances whose flowers were scarcely withered. It excited him, too, that many men had already loved Daisy—it increased her value in his eyes. He felt their presence all about the house, pervading the air with the shades and echoes of still vibrant emotions.  

But he knew that he was in Daisy’s house by a colossal accident. However glorious might be his future as Jay Gatsby, he was at present a penniless young man without a past, and at any moment the invisible cloak of his uniform might slip from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took what he could get, ravenously and unscrupulously—eventually he took Daisy one still October night, took her because he had no real right to touch her hand.  

He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretenses. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same stratum as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.  

But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.  

When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.  

“I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, ‘way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”  

On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised. They had never been closer in their month of love, nor communicated more profoundly one with another, than when she brushed silent lips against his coat’s shoulder or when he touched the end of her fingers, gently, as though she were asleep.  

---

### Key Improvements:  
1. **Restored Narrative Transitions** – The opening now includes Nick’s observation about Gatsby’s broken reserve, better framing the confession.  
2. **Full Sensory Details** – The description of Daisy’s house is richer, emphasizing its mystery and allure.  
3. **Precise Emotional Arc** – Gatsby’s internal conflict is rendered with greater nuance, particularly his self-awareness about deception.  
4. **Final Intimacy Preserved** – The last afternoon’s silent gestures and profound connection are included, maintaining the original’s emotional weight.  
5. **Tonal Accuracy** – Gatsby’s dialogue retains Fitzgerald’s layered subtlety, and Nick’s narrative voice remains dominant.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. The illusion had shattered, and for the first time, I saw the man beneath the myth, raw and vulnerable.  

Gatsby leaned back in his chair, his usual poise gone, replaced by a weariness that seemed to age him before my eyes. The champagne in his glass had long gone flat, but he didn’t seem to notice. His voice, when he spoke, was quiet, almost as if he were talking to himself.  

“I was seventeen when I met Dan Cody,” he began. “James Gatz was my name then—just a boy from North Dakota with nothing but dreams too big for his own good.” He smiled faintly, as if recalling the absurdity of his own ambition. “I’d been working along the shore of Lake Superior, fishing, odd jobs—anything to keep from starving. Then one day, I saw his yacht, the *Tuolomee*, anchored in the shallows. It was the most beautiful thing I’d ever seen.”  

There was something wistful in his tone, the way one speaks of a first love. I could almost picture him—a sunburned, hungry boy, staring at that yacht like it was a gateway to another world.  

“I rowed out to warn him about a coming storm,” Gatsby continued. “Cody took a liking to me. Asked me my name, and right then, I decided to be someone else. ‘Jay Gatsby,’ I told him. Just like that.” He snapped his fingers, the sound sharp in the quiet room. “Dan Cody became everything to me—father, mentor, the man who showed me what wealth could do. He took me on as his assistant, and for five years, I sailed with him, learned from him. He had money, real money, not like the people here with their old names and borrowed prestige.”  

There was bitterness there, a resentment that had festered over the years. Gatsby had built his fortune, but it had never been enough to erase where he came from.  

“What happened to him?” I asked.  

Gatsby’s expression darkened. “He died. Left me twenty-five thousand dollars in his will, but his mistress, Ella Kaye, made sure I never saw a cent of it. She had lawyers, connections—I was nobody again.” He laughed, a hollow sound. “But I learned something from Cody. I learned how to be rich. And I swore I’d never be that boy on the shore again, watching from the outside.”  

For a moment, he was silent, lost in memory. Then, with a sudden intensity, he looked at me. “You see, old sport, it was never just about the money. It was about becoming someone who *deserved* her. Someone who could walk into a room and have everyone turn their heads.”  

*Her.* Daisy. The name hung between us, unspoken but deafening.  

“And now?” I asked carefully.  

Gatsby’s face tightened. “Now Tom’s told her everything. About the bootlegging, about Wolfsheim. She looked at me like I was a stranger.” His voice cracked. “Like I was *nothing*.”  

The clock on the mantel ticked loudly in the silence. Outside, the first light of dawn was creeping over the water, turning the sky a pale, sickly gray. The party was over in more ways than one.  

“What will you do?” I asked.  

He didn’t answer at first. Then, with a quiet determination, he said, “I’ll wait. She’ll come back. She has to.”  

But even as he said it, I knew he didn’t believe it. The dream was dead, and Gatsby—the man who had spun gold out of nothing—was finally facing the truth.  

He stood abruptly, as if he could no longer bear to sit still. “I think I’ll go for a swim,” he said, forcing a smile. “Clear my head.”  

I wanted to stop him, to say something—anything—that might ease the pain in his eyes. But the words wouldn’t come. So I just nodded, and watched as he walked out into the pale morning light, alone.  

It was the last time I ever saw him alive.

events.title: War, Oxford, Daisy's Impatience, and Gatsby's Return
detailed_summary: Gatsby performed well in the war, reaching the rank of Major, but complications sent him to Oxford afterwards instead of home.
Daisy's letters became nervously desperate; she felt external pressures and needed Gatsby's reassurance.
Her world of privilege, parties, and social expectations pushed her towards making a decision about her life.
She resumed dating multiple men, caught between her feelings for Gatsby and the need for immediate security.
Tom Buchanan arrived, representing stability and wealth, flattering Daisy.
She married Tom, a decision likely involving both struggle and relief; Gatsby received her letter while at Oxford.
As dawn breaks at Gatsby's house, he insists to Nick that Daisy never loved Tom, or only briefly, claiming her confession was coerced.
Gatsby makes the enigmatic comment that the affair 'was just personal'.
After the war, penniless, Gatsby travelled to Louisville while Tom and Daisy were on their honeymoon.
He revisited places he and Daisy shared, finding the city imbued with melancholy beauty due to her absence.
Leaving Louisville by train, he felt he hadn't searched hard enough, that he was leaving her behind.
He watched the city fade, feeling he had lost the best part of his past forever.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He did extraordinarily well in the war.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

events.text_segment:
He did extraordinarily well in the war. He was a captain before he went to the front, and following the Argonne battles he got his majority and the command of the divisional machine-guns. After the armistice he tried frantically to get home, but some complication or misunderstanding sent him to Oxford instead. He was worried now—there was a quality of nervous despair in Daisy’s letters. She didn’t see why he couldn’t come. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence beside her and be reassured that she was doing the right thing after all.
For Daisy was young and her artificial world was redolent of orchids and pleasant, cheerful snobbery and orchestras which set the rhythm of the year, summing up the sadness and suggestiveness of life in new tunes. All night the saxophones wailed the hopeless comment of the “Beale Street Blues” while a hundred pairs of golden and silver slippers shuffled the shining dust. At the grey tea hour there were always rooms that throbbed incessantly with this low, sweet fever, while fresh faces drifted here and there like rose petals blown by the sad horns around the floor.
Through this twilight universe Daisy began to move again with the season; suddenly she was again keeping half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen men, and drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening-dress tangled among dying orchids on the floor beside her bed. And all the time something within her was crying for a decision. She wanted her life shaped now, immediately—and the decision must be made by some force—of love, of money, of unquestionable practicality—that was close at hand.
That force took shape in the middle of spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. There was a wholesome bulkiness about his person and his position, and Daisy was flattered. Doubtless there was a certain struggle and a certain relief. The letter reached Gatsby while he was still at Oxford.
It was dawn now on Long Island and we went about opening the rest of the windows downstairs, filling the house with grey-turning, gold-turning light. The shadow of a tree fell abruptly across the dew and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a slow, pleasant movement in the air, scarcely a wind, promising a cool, lovely day.
“I don’t think she ever loved him.” Gatsby turned around from a window and looked at me challengingly. “You must remember, old sport, she was very excited this afternoon. He told her those things in a way that frightened her—that made it look as if I was some kind of cheap sharper. And the result was she hardly knew what she was saying.”
He sat down gloomily.
“Of course she might have loved him just for a minute, when they were first married—and loved me more even then, do you see?”
Suddenly he came out with a curious remark.
“In any case,” he said, “it was just personal.”
What could you make of that, except to suspect some intensity in his conception of the affair that couldn’t be measured?
He came back from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their wedding trip, and made a miserable but irresistible journey to Louisville on the last of his army pay. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had clicked together through the November night and revisiting the out-of-the-way places to which they had driven in her white car. Just as Daisy’s house had always seemed to him more mysterious and gay than other houses, so his idea of the city itself, even though she was gone from it, was pervaded with a melancholy beauty.
He left feeling that if he had searched harder, he might have found her—that he was leaving her behind. The day-coach—he was penniless now—was hot. He went out to the open vestibule and sat down on a folding-chair, and the station slid away and the backs of unfamiliar buildings moved by. Then out into the spring fields, where a yellow trolley raced them for a minute with people in it who might once have seen the pale magic of her face along the casual street.
The track curved and now it was going away from the sun, which, as it sank lower, seemed to spread itself in benediction over the vanishing city where she had drawn her breath. He stretched out his hand desperately as if to snatch only a wisp of air, to save a fragment of the spot that she had made lovely for him. But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

Here is the original passage from *The Great Gatsby* by F. Scott Fitzgerald that corresponds to the provided metadata:

---

**text_segment**:  
*"He did extraordinarily well in the war. He was a captain before he went to the front, and following the Argonne battles he got his majority and the command of the divisional machine-guns. After the Armistice he tried frantically to get home, but some complication or misunderstanding sent him to Oxford instead. He was worried now—there was a quality of nervous despair in Daisy’s letters. She didn’t see why he couldn’t come. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence beside her and be reassured that she was doing the right thing after all.  

For Daisy was young and her artificial world was redolent of orchids and pleasant, cheerful snobbery and orchestras which set the rhythm of the year, summing up the sadness and suggestiveness of life in new tunes. All night the saxophones wailed the hopeless comment of the 'Beale Street Blues' while a hundred pairs of golden and silver slippers shuffled the shining dust. At the gray tea hour there were always rooms that throbbed incessantly with this low, sweet fever, while fresh faces drifted here and there like rose petals blown by the sad horns around the floor.  

Through this twilight universe Daisy began to move again with the season; suddenly she was again keeping half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen men, and drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening dress tangled among dying orchids on the floor beside her bed. And all the time something within her was crying for a decision. She wanted her life shaped now, immediately—and the decision must be made by some force—of love, of money, of unquestionable practicality—that was close at hand.  

That force took shape in the middle of spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. There was a wholesome bulkiness about his person and his position, and Daisy was flattered. Doubtless there was a certain struggle and a certain relief. The letter reached Gatsby at Oxford.  

It was dawn now on Long Island and we went about opening the rest of the windows downstairs, filling the house with gray-turning, gold-turning light. The shadow of a tree fell abruptly across the dew and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a slow, pleasant movement in the air, scarcely a wind, promising a cool, lovely day.  

'I don’t think she ever loved him,' Gatsby turned around from a window and looked at me challengingly. 'You must remember, old sport, she was very excited this afternoon. He told her those things in a way that frightened her—that made it look as if I was some kind of cheap sharper. And the result was she hardly knew what she was saying.'  

He sat down gloomily.  

'Of course she might have loved him just for a minute, when they were first married—and loved me more even then, do you see?'  

Suddenly he came out with a curious remark.  

'In any case,' he said, 'it was just personal.'  

What could you make of that, except to suspect some intensity in his conception of the affair that couldn’t be measured?  

When he came back from France, Tom and Daisy were still on their wedding trip, and he made a miserable but irresistible journey to Louisville on the money he was saving. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had clicked together through the November night and revisiting the out-of-the-way places to which they had driven in her white car. Just as Daisy’s house had seemed to him more mysterious and gay than other houses, so his idea of the city itself, even though she was gone from it, was pervaded with a melancholy beauty.  

He left, feeling that if he had searched harder, he might have found her—that he was leaving her behind. The day-coach—he was penniless now—was hot. He went out to the open vestibule and sat down on a folding-chair, and the station slid away and the backs of unfamiliar buildings moved by. Then out into the spring fields, where a yellow trolley raced them for a minute with people in it who might once have seen the pale magic of her face along the casual street.  

The track curved and now it was going away from the sun, which, as it sank lower, seemed to spread itself in benediction over the vanishing city where she had drawn her breath. He stretched out his hand desperately as if to snatch only a wisp of air, to save a fragment of the spot that she had made lovely for him. But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever."*  

---

This passage aligns with the provided metadata, including the chapter title (VIII), the characters involved (Gatsby, Daisy, Tom, Nick), and the detailed summary of events. Let me know if you'd like any refinements!

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He did extraordinarily well in the war. It was one of the few things in his life that had not been tainted by the weight of expectation or the shadow of his past. In the trenches of France, Jay Gatsby was no longer the poor farm boy from North Dakota, nor the ambitious young man clawing his way up the social ladder. He was simply a soldier—brave, disciplined, and, for the first time, truly free.  

The war had given him purpose. Unlike the hollow pursuits of wealth and status that would later consume him, the battlefield demanded something real: courage, sacrifice, endurance. And Gatsby, ever the romantic, threw himself into it with the same fervor he would later apply to his grand illusions. He rose quickly through the ranks, not through connections or charm, but through sheer competence. His superiors noted his coolness under fire, his ability to lead men who had once doubted him. By the time the Armistice was signed, he had been decorated for valor, a fact he rarely spoke of but carried with him like a hidden medal, polished only in the quietest moments of reflection.  

It was in the war, too, that he met Dan Cody, the man who would become his first real mentor. Cody, a wealthy copper magnate turned officer, saw something in Gatsby—not just the sharp mind or the relentless drive, but the hunger for something greater. In those long nights at camp, Cody spun tales of fortunes made and lost, of a world where a man could remake himself entirely. Gatsby listened, enraptured. The war had shown him that he could be more than his origins; Cody’s stories convinced him that he could be anything.  

And then there was Daisy.  

She was not yet Daisy Buchanan then, but Daisy Fay of Louisville, a vision in white who had captured the hearts of half a dozen officers. Gatsby met her at a dance, one of those glittering affairs held to distract the soldiers from the grim reality waiting for them overseas. He was in uniform, his lieutenant’s bars gleaming, and for once, he felt he belonged. Daisy, with her bright laughter and careless grace, seemed to see him not as an impostor, but as a hero. In her eyes, he was already the man he longed to be.  

Their romance was brief but intoxicating. Gatsby, who had spent his life reaching for something just out of grasp, finally held it in his hands. Daisy promised to wait for him, her letters arriving in smudged envelopes that he carried with him like sacred relics. But war has a way of distorting time, and by the time he returned, the world had shifted. Daisy had married Tom Buchanan, a man of old money and brutal certainty, and Gatsby’s dreams were deferred—but never abandoned.  

The war had changed him in ways he did not yet understand. It had given him discipline, yes, and a taste of glory, but it had also sharpened his capacity for self-deception. He had learned to survive in a world where death was a constant companion, where the line between reality and illusion blurred in the smoke of artillery fire. That skill would serve him well in the years to come, as he built a fortune on shaky foundations and convinced himself that the past could be rewritten.  

In the end, the war was both his making and his undoing. It taught him that a man could rise above his station, but it also convinced him that love, like victory, could be won through sheer force of will. And so, when he stood on the dock of his West Egg mansion, staring across the bay at the green light on Daisy’s pier, he was not just a man reaching for a woman—he was a soldier still fighting a war he could never quite leave behind.  

He did extraordinarily well in the war. But the greatest battle of his life was one he could never win.

events.title: Nick's Departure and Final Words to Gatsby
detailed_summary: After breakfast, the weather feels autumnal.
Gatsby's gardener plans to drain the pool, but Gatsby asks him to wait, telling Nick he hasn't used it all summer.
Nick feels reluctant to leave Gatsby for work in the city and misses several trains.
He promises to call Gatsby around noon.
As they walk down the steps, Gatsby anxiously hopes Daisy will call.
Nick reassures him.
As Nick walks away, he turns back and shouts across the lawn that Gatsby is worth more than the 'rotten crowd' he associates with.
Nick reflects that this was his only compliment to Gatsby, despite disapproving of him.
Gatsby responds with a radiant, understanding smile.
Nick remembers first arriving at Gatsby's house months earlier, contrasting the past crowds with Gatsby's solitary stance concealing his 'incorruptible dream'.
Nick thanks Gatsby for his hospitality and says goodbye.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

events.text_segment:
It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The night had made a sharp difference in the weather and there was an autumn flavour in the air. The gardener, the last one of Gatsby’s former servants, came to the foot of the steps.
“I’m going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby. Leaves’ll start falling pretty soon, and then there’s always trouble with the pipes.”
“Don’t do it today,” Gatsby answered. He turned to me apologetically. “You know, old sport, I’ve never used that pool all summer?”
I looked at my watch and stood up.
“Twelve minutes to my train.”
I didn’t want to go to the city. I wasn’t worth a decent stroke of work, but it was more than that—I didn’t want to leave Gatsby. I missed that train, and then another, before I could get myself away.
“I’ll call you up,” I said finally.
“Do, old sport.”
“I’ll call you about noon.”
We walked slowly down the steps.
“I suppose Daisy’ll call too.” He looked at me anxiously, as if he hoped I’d corroborate this.
“I suppose so.”
“Well, goodbye.”
We shook hands and I started away. Just before I reached the hedge I remembered something and turned around.
“They’re a rotten crowd,” I shouted across the lawn. “You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together.”
I’ve always been glad I said that. It was the only compliment I ever gave him, because I disapproved of him from beginning to end. First he nodded politely, and then his face broke into that radiant and understanding smile, as if we’d been in ecstatic cahoots on that fact all the time. His gorgeous pink rag of a suit made a bright spot of colour against the white steps, and I thought of the night when I first came to his ancestral home, three months before. The lawn and drive had been crowded with the faces of those who guessed at his corruption—and he had stood on those steps, concealing his incorruptible dream, as he waved them goodbye.
I thanked him for his hospitality. We were always thanking him for that—I and the others.
“Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

*It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The night had made a sharp difference in the weather and there was an autumn flavor in the air. The gardener, the last one of Gatsby’s former servants, came to the foot of the steps.*  

*“I’m going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby. Leaves’ll start falling pretty soon, and then there’s always trouble with the pipes.”*  

*“Don’t do it today,” Gatsby answered. He turned to me apologetically. “You know, old sport, I’ve never used that pool all summer?”*  

*I looked at my watch and stood up.*  

*“Twelve minutes to my train.”*  

*I didn’t want to go to the city. I wasn’t worth a decent stroke of work, but it was more than that—I didn’t want to leave Gatsby. I missed that train, and then another, before I could get myself away.*  

*“I’ll call you up,” I said finally.*  

*“Do, old sport.”*  

*“I’ll call you about noon.”*  

*We walked slowly down the steps.*  

*“I suppose Daisy’ll call too.” He looked at me anxiously, as if he hoped I’d corroborate this.*  

*“I suppose so.”*  

*“Well, goodbye.”*  

*We shook hands and I started away. Just before I reached the hedge I remembered something and turned around.*  

*“They’re a rotten crowd,” I shouted across the lawn. “You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together.”*  

*I’ve always been glad I said that. It was the only compliment I ever gave him, because I disapproved of him from beginning to end. First he nodded politely, and then his face broke into that radiant and understanding smile, as if we’d been in ecstatic cahoots on that fact all the time. His gorgeous pink rag of a suit made a bright spot of color against the white steps, and I thought of the first time I saw him, months ago, standing in his lawn with his hands in his pockets, regarding the silver pepper of the stars. Something in his leisurely movements and the secure position of his feet upon the lawn suggested that it was Mr. Gatsby’s own lawn he was standing on and that he had come out to determine what share was his of our local heavens.*  

*I called goodbye again from the steps, and he waved and smiled back at me. Then I walked down the path to the station, leaving him there—watching over nothing.*

- The original contains a recollection of a specific night three months prior, involving a crowded lawn and Gatsby’s demeanor as he bid farewell to guests, which is missing from the completion.

- The final direct farewell and mention of enjoying breakfast are absent.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The morning was already warm, the sun casting long shadows across the lawn, and the air thick with the scent of honeysuckle. Gatsby stood at the railing, his hands in his pockets, staring out at the water with that familiar, restless intensity. There was something almost tragic in the way he watched the green light across the bay—Daisy’s light—as if it held the answer to everything he had ever wanted.  

Nick and I lingered nearby, sipping coffee in silence. The events of the previous night hung between us, unspoken but heavy. Gatsby’s extravagant parties, the careless laughter, the way Daisy had looked at him—it all felt like a dream slipping away in the harsh morning light.  

“You can’t repeat the past,” Nick had said to him earlier, but Gatsby, ever the dreamer, had replied with that stubborn conviction of his: *“Can’t repeat the past? Why, of course you can!”*  

Now, standing there in the quiet, I wondered if he truly believed it. Or if, deep down, he knew that time was slipping through his fingers like sand, that no amount of wealth or grandeur could turn back the clock.  

A breeze stirred the leaves, and Gatsby turned to us suddenly, his face alight with that same boyish hope. “What do you say we take the car into town?” he suggested, as if movement could outrun the inevitable.  

Nick hesitated, but I nodded. There was something magnetic about Gatsby’s energy, something that made you want to believe in his illusions, if only for a little while longer.  

As we drove off, the mansion receding behind us, I couldn’t shake the feeling that we were racing toward something—not just the city, but the unraveling of a dream too fragile to last. The sun was high now, the day stretching ahead, full of promise and peril. And Gatsby, ever the optimist, smiled as if he hadn’t a care in the world.

events.title: Nick's Distracted Day and Breakup with Jordan
detailed_summary: In the city, Nick is unable to focus on work and falls asleep.
He's awakened by a phone call from Jordan Baker just before noon.
Jordan sounds harsh and dry, unlike her usual cool tone.
She informs Nick she has left Daisy's house and is heading to Southampton.
Nick is annoyed by her departure from Daisy's.
Jordan confronts Nick about his behavior the previous night.
Their conversation becomes stilted and awkward as they arrange, then cancel, plans to meet.
The call ends abruptly, with Nick realizing their relationship is over and feeling indifferent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.

events.text_segment:
Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair. Just before noon the phone woke me, and I started up with sweat breaking out on my forehead. It was Jordan Baker; she often called me up at this hour because the uncertainty of her own movements between hotels and clubs and private houses made her hard to find in any other way. Usually her voice came over the wire as something fresh and cool, as if a divot from a green golf-links had come sailing in at the office window, but this morning it seemed harsh and dry.
“I’ve left Daisy’s house,” she said. “I’m at Hempstead, and I’m going down to Southampton this afternoon.”
Probably it had been tactful to leave Daisy’s house, but the act annoyed me, and her next remark made me rigid.
“You weren’t so nice to me last night.”
“How could it have mattered then?”
Silence for a moment. Then:
“However—I want to see you.”
“I want to see you, too.”
“Suppose I don’t go to Southampton, and come into town this afternoon?”
“No—I don’t think this afternoon.”
“Very well.”
“It’s impossible this afternoon. Various—”
We talked like that for a while, and then abruptly we weren’t talking any longer. I don’t know which of us hung up with a sharp click, but I know I didn’t care. I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair. The office was stifling, the air thick with the scent of ink and stale coffee, the ceaseless hum of ticker-tape machines lulling me into a daze. Outside, the streets of New York pulsed with life—men in sharp suits rushing to appointments, taxis honking in impatient succession—but inside, the monotony of numbers and figures weighed on me like a leaden blanket.  

I dreamed of West Egg, of the green light flickering across the bay, of Gatsby’s mansion glowing against the night. Even in sleep, the city’s relentless rhythm pursued me—the clatter of typewriters, the distant wail of a siren, the murmur of brokers discussing fortunes made and lost before lunch. When I awoke, the afternoon sun slanted through the blinds, casting long shadows over my desk. The stock listings blurred before my tired eyes, and for a moment, I wondered if any of it mattered—the numbers, the money, the endless striving.  

Somewhere beyond the glass and steel, beyond the reach of Wall Street’s grasping fingers, Gatsby was still reaching too—not for wealth, but for something far more elusive. And as the city roared on, indifferent, I found myself longing for the quiet desperation of Long Island, where at least the dreams were grand enough to drown out the silence.

events.title: Failed Call to Gatsby and Wilson's Grief-Stricken Vigil
detailed_summary: Nick attempts to call Gatsby several times but finds the line busy, eventually learning it's held for a long-distance call from Detroit.
He plans to take the 3:50 train.
The narrative shifts focus back to the previous night at Wilson's garage after the accident.
Nick reflects on passing the ash-heaps earlier, deliberately avoiding the scene.
Myrtle's sister, Catherine, arrived drunk and distraught, fainting when told the ambulance had already left.
George Wilson remained inside the garage, rocking in grief, while a crowd gathered outside.
Michaelis, the neighboring restaurant owner, stayed with Wilson throughout the night, along with a few other men initially.
Eventually, Michaelis sent the last stranger away and remained alone with Wilson until dawn, making coffee to stay awake.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.

events.text_segment:
I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I tried four times; finally an exasperated central told me the wire was being kept open for long distance from Detroit. Taking out my timetable, I drew a small circle around the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair and tried to think. It was just noon.
When I passed the ash-heaps on the train that morning I had crossed deliberately to the other side of the car. I supposed there’d be a curious crowd around there all day with little boys searching for dark spots in the dust, and some garrulous man telling over and over what had happened, until it became less and less real even to him and he could tell it no longer, and Myrtle Wilson’s tragic achievement was forgotten. Now I want to go back a little and tell what happened at the garage after we left there the night before.
They had difficulty in locating the sister, Catherine. She must have broken her rule against drinking that night, for when she arrived she was stupid with liquor and unable to understand that the ambulance had already gone to Flushing. When they convinced her of this, she immediately fainted, as if that was the intolerable part of the affair. Someone, kind or curious, took her in his car and drove her in the wake of her sister’s body.
Until long after midnight a changing crowd lapped up against the front of the garage, while George Wilson rocked himself back and forth on the couch inside. For a while the door of the office was open, and everyone who came into the garage glanced irresistibly through it. Finally someone said it was a shame, and closed the door. Michaelis and several other men were with him; first, four or five men, later two or three men. Still later Michaelis had to ask the last stranger to wait there fifteen minutes longer, while he went back to his own place and made a pot of coffee. After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
**text_segment**:  

*I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I tried four times; finally an exasperated central told me the wire was being kept open for long distance from Detroit. Taking out my time-table I drew a small circle around the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair and tried to think. It was just noon.*  

*When I passed the ashheaps that morning I had crossed deliberately to the other side of the car. I suppose that was because I didn’t want to see the scene of the accident—but I saw it, anyway, grotesque and incongruous in the bright raw sunlight. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg kept their vigil, but I perceived, after a moment, that other eyes were regarding us with peculiar intensity from less than twenty feet away.*  

*In one of the windows over the garage the curtains had been moved aside a little, and Myrtle Wilson was peering down at the car. So engrossed was she that she had no consciousness of being observed, and one emotion after another crept into her face like objects into a slowly developing picture. Her expression was curiously familiar—it was an expression I had often seen on women’s faces, but on Myrtle Wilson’s face it seemed purposeless and inexplicable until I realized that her eyes, wide with jealous terror, were fixed not on Tom, but on Jordan Baker, whom she took to be his wife.*  

*There is no confusion like the confusion of a simple mind, and as we drove away Tom was feeling the hot whips of panic. His wife and his mistress, until an hour ago secure and inviolate, were slipping precipitately from his control.*  

*“They’ll keep out of my way,” he said. “I’ll make them keep out of my way.”*  

*He turned to me. “I suppose I ought to let you off at West Egg, Nick. There’s no use your coming along for the trouble I’m in.”*  

*“I’ll go with you,” I said.*  

*He glared at me for a moment as though he couldn’t understand why I wasn’t properly impressed by his generosity. Then the whistle of the locomotive, the Pennsylvania one, coming in on time, made him turn his head away sharply. “I think I’ll go over to New York this afternoon,” he said, as though continuing a conversation interrupted hours before.*  

*“You’d better let me drive,” I suggested.*  

*“No, I’ll drive.”*  

*He took the wheel, and we started back to Long Island in the late afternoon sun. We didn’t talk. Tom was sunk in a profound gloom, and I was conscious of a pervading uneasiness. When we reached the valley of ashes it was twilight. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, dimmed a little by many paintless days under sun and rain, brooded on over the solemn dumping ground.*  

*“You’re wasting your time,” I said suddenly. “She’ll see you tomorrow.”*  

*“I’m not going to wait till tomorrow,” he snapped. “I’m not going to wait at all.”*  

*“But you can’t just barge in—”*  

*“Can’t I?” he said furiously. “You watch me.”*  

*He stopped the car abruptly in front of Wilson’s garage. I had never been there before, but I recognized it from Myrtle’s description—a small block of yellow brick sitting on the edge of the waste land, a sort of compact Main Street ministering to it, and contiguous to absolutely nothing. One of the three shops it contained was for rent and another was an all-night restaurant, approachable by a trail of ashes; the third was a garage—Repairs. George B. Wilson. Cars bought and sold.—and we followed Tom inside.*  

*The interior was unprosperous and bare; the only car visible was the dust-covered wreck of a Ford which crouched in a dim corner. It had occurred to me that this shadow of a garage must be a blind, and that sumptuous and romantic apartments were concealed overhead, when the proprietor himself appeared in the door of an office, wiping his hands on a piece of waste. He was a blond, spiritless man, anaemic, and faintly handsome. When he saw us a damp gleam of hope sprang into his light blue eyes.*  

*“Hello, Wilson, old man,” said Tom, slapping him jovially on the shoulder. “How’s business?”*  

*“I can’t complain,” answered Wilson unconvincingly. “When are you going to sell me that car?”*  

*“Next week; I’ve got my man working on it now.”*  

*“Works pretty slow, don’t he?”*  

*“No, he doesn’t,” said Tom coldly. “And if you feel that way about it, maybe I’d better sell it somewhere else after all.”*  

*“I don’t mean that,” explained Wilson quickly. “I just meant—”*  

*His voice faded off and Tom glanced impatiently around the garage. Then I heard footsteps on a stairs, and in a moment the thickish figure of a woman blocked out the light from the office door. She was in the middle thirties, and faintly stout, but she carried her surplus flesh sensuously as some women can. Her face, above a spotted dress of dark blue crepe-de-chine, contained no facet or gleam of beauty, but there was an immediately perceptible vitality about her as if the nerves of her body were continually smouldering. She smiled slowly and, walking through her husband as if he were a ghost, shook hands with Tom, looking him flush in the eye. Then she wet her lips, and without turning around spoke to her husband in a soft, coarse voice:*  

*“Get some chairs, why don’t you, so somebody can sit down.”*  

*“Oh, sure,” agreed Wilson hurriedly, and went toward the little office, mingling immediately with the cement color of the walls. A white ashen dust veiled his dark suit and his pale hair as it veiled everything in the vicinity—except his wife, who moved close to Tom.*  

*“I want to see you,” said Tom intently. “Get on the next train.”*  

*“All right.”*  

*“I’ll meet you by the news-stand on the lower level.”*  

*She nodded and moved away from him just as George Wilson emerged with two chairs from his office door.*  

*We waited for her down the road and out of sight. It was a few days before the Fourth of July, and a gray, scrawny Italian child was setting torpedoes in a row along the railroad track.*  

*“Terrible place, isn’t it,” said Tom, exchanging a frown with Doctor Eckleburg.*  

*“Awful.”*  

*“It does her good to get away.”*  

*“Doesn’t her husband object?”*  

*“Wilson? He thinks she goes to see her sister in New York. He’s so dumb he doesn’t know he’s alive.”*  

*So Tom Buchanan and his wife and his mistress were still linked together in a sort of grotesque and senseless bond. I drove on toward death through the cooling twilight.*  

*The next night at the garage, after the accident, Catherine arrived drunk and hysterical. She fainted when they told her the ambulance had already gone. Wilson stayed inside the garage, rocking himself back and forth on a couch. Michaelis, the Greek who ran the restaurant next door, was with him until dawn. At first there were four or five men, then two, then just Michaelis. He made coffee for Wilson and stayed with him until it was light enough to go out and look for the car.*  

*By that time the crowd had gone, and only the policemen remained, standing in the road and talking in low voices. The sun was coming up, and the shadows of the ashheaps stretched out over the valley, long and thin, like fingers reaching for something they could not quite touch.*

**text_segment**:  

*I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I tried four times; finally an exasperated central told me the wire was being kept open for long distance from Detroit. Taking out my time-table I drew a small circle around the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair and tried to think. It was just noon.*  

*When I passed the ashheaps that morning I had crossed deliberately to the other side of the car. I suppose that was because I didn’t want to see the scene of the accident—but I saw it, anyway, grotesque and incongruous in the bright raw sunlight. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg kept their vigil, but I perceived, after a moment, that other eyes were regarding us with peculiar intensity from less than twenty feet away.*  

*In one of the windows over the garage the curtains had been moved aside a little, and Myrtle Wilson was peering down at the car. So engrossed was she that she had no consciousness of being observed, and one emotion after another crept into her face like objects into a slowly developing picture. Her expression was curiously familiar—it was an expression I had often seen on women’s faces, but on Myrtle Wilson’s face it seemed purposeless and inexplicable until I realized that her eyes, wide with jealous terror, were fixed not on Tom, but on Jordan Baker, whom she took to be his wife.*  

*There is no confusion like the confusion of a simple mind, and as we drove away Tom was feeling the hot whips of panic. His wife and his mistress, until an hour ago secure and inviolate, were slipping precipitately from his control.*  

*“They’ll keep out of my way,” he said. “I’ll make them keep out of my way.”*  

*He turned to me. “I suppose I ought to let you off at West Egg, Nick. There’s no use your coming along for the trouble I’m in.”*  

*“I’ll go with you,” I said.*  

*He glared at me for a moment as though he couldn’t understand why I wasn’t properly impressed by his generosity. Then the whistle of the locomotive, the Pennsylvania one, coming in on time, made him turn his head away sharply. “I think I’ll go over to New York this afternoon,” he said, as though continuing a conversation interrupted hours before.*  

*“You’d better let me drive,” I suggested.*  

*“No, I’ll drive.”*  

*He took the wheel, and we started back to Long Island in the late afternoon sun. We didn’t talk. Tom was sunk in a profound gloom, and I was conscious of a pervading uneasiness. When we reached the valley of ashes it was twilight. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, dimmed a little by many paintless days under sun and rain, brooded on over the solemn dumping ground.*  

*“You’re wasting your time,” I said suddenly. “She’ll see you tomorrow.”*  

*“I’m not going to wait till tomorrow,” he snapped. “I’m not going to wait at all.”*  

*“But you can’t just barge in—”*  

*“Can’t I?” he said furiously. “You watch me.”*  

*He stopped the car abruptly in front of Wilson’s garage. I had never been there before, but I recognized it from Myrtle’s description—a small block of yellow brick sitting on the edge of the waste land, a sort of compact Main Street ministering to it, and contiguous to absolutely nothing. One of the three shops it contained was for rent and another was an all-night restaurant, approachable by a trail of ashes; the third was a garage—Repairs. George B. Wilson. Cars bought and sold.—and we followed Tom inside.*  

*The interior was unprosperous and bare; the only car visible was the dust-covered wreck of a Ford which crouched in a dim corner. It had occurred to me that this shadow of a garage must be a blind, and that sumptuous and romantic apartments were concealed overhead, when the proprietor himself appeared in the door of an office, wiping his hands on a piece of waste. He was a blond, spiritless man, anaemic, and faintly handsome. When he saw us a damp gleam of hope sprang into his light blue eyes.*  

*“Hello, Wilson, old man,” said Tom, slapping him jovially on the shoulder. “How’s business?”*  

*“I can’t complain,” answered Wilson unconvincingly. “When are you going to sell me that car?”*  

*“Next week; I’ve got my man working on it now.”*

*“No, he doesn’t,” said Tom coldly. “And if you feel that way about it, maybe I’d better sell it somewhere else after all.”*  

*“I don’t mean that,” explained Wilson quickly. “I just meant—”*  

*His voice faded off and Tom glanced impatiently around the garage. Then I heard footsteps on a stairs, and in a moment the thickish figure of a woman blocked out the light from the office door. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I hung up the receiver with a sigh, wondering who could be speaking to him at this late hour. The night was thick with humidity, and the distant hum of a lone automobile on the road only deepened the silence of my empty house.  

I tried again after a quarter of an hour, but still, the line refused to yield. A strange unease settled over me—perhaps it was the lingering tension from the afternoon, or the way Daisy’s voice had trembled when she last spoke of him. Gatsby’s world was one of perpetual motion, of parties that never truly ended, yet now, in this moment, he was unreachable.  

I considered driving over, but something held me back. The image of his mansion, lit like a beacon against the dark Long Island shore, flashed in my mind. How many times had I seen it glowing from across the bay, alive with music and laughter? And yet tonight, it might as well have been a fortress, its master locked away in some private struggle.  

The operator’s voice cut in, mechanical and indifferent: *"The line is still busy. Would you like to try again later?"* I declined, setting the phone down with a quiet click.  

It was then that I noticed the first drops of rain against the window—soft, hesitant, as if the sky itself were uncertain. I thought of Gatsby standing alone in that vast house, the telephone pressed to his ear, speaking to someone who might never truly understand him. Or perhaps he wasn’t speaking at all. Perhaps he was simply waiting, as he always had been, for a voice that would never come.  

The rain grew heavier, drumming against the roof, and I knew then that some connections are never meant to be made, no matter how many times one tries.

events.title: Wilson's Dawning Suspicion and Ominous Resolve
detailed_summary: Around 3 a.m., Wilson grows quieter and starts talking about the yellow car, claiming he knows how to find its owner.
He mentions Myrtle returning from the city months ago with bruises.
Overcome with grief, he cries out again.
Michaelis tries to distract Wilson with questions about his marriage and children.
Michaelis feels uneasy, disturbed by passing cars and the stained workbench where Myrtle's body lay.
He suggests calling a priest, but Wilson says he doesn't belong to a church.
Wilson directs Michaelis to a drawer containing a small, expensive, new-looking dog leash braided with silver.
Wilson reveals he found it the previous afternoon and suspected something 'funny'.
Michaelis offers innocent explanations, but Wilson, likely having heard similar excuses from Myrtle, becomes distressed again.
Wilson suddenly declares, 'Then he killed her,' convinced it wasn't an accident.
He believes Myrtle ran out to speak to the man in the car who wouldn't stop.
Wilson begins rocking again.
As dawn breaks, Wilson looks out at the ash-heaps.
He mutters about confronting Myrtle, telling her she couldn't fool God.
He walks to the window, indicating he told her this while looking out.
Michaelis realizes with shock that Wilson is staring directly at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg on the billboard.
Wilson repeats, 'God sees everything,' while Michaelis weakly insists it's just an advertisement.
Wilson remains at the window, nodding into the twilight.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.

events.text_segment:
About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. He announced that he had a way of finding out whom the yellow car belonged to, and then he blurted out that a couple of months ago his wife had come from the city with her face bruised and her nose swollen.
But when he heard himself say this, he flinched and began to cry “Oh, my God!” again in his groaning voice. Michaelis made a clumsy attempt to distract him.
“How long have you been married, George? Come on there, try and sit still a minute, and answer my question. How long have you been married?”
“Twelve years.”
“Ever had any children? Come on, George, sit still—I asked you a question. Did you ever have any children?”
The hard brown beetles kept thudding against the dull light, and whenever Michaelis heard a car go tearing along the road outside it sounded to him like the car that hadn’t stopped a few hours before. He didn’t like to go into the garage, because the work bench was stained where the body had been lying, so he moved uncomfortably around the office—he knew every object in it before morning—and from time to time sat down beside Wilson trying to keep him more quiet.
“Have you got a church you go to sometimes, George? Maybe even if you haven’t been there for a long time? Maybe I could call up the church and get a priest to come over and he could talk to you, see?”
“Don’t belong to any.”
“You ought to have a church, George, for times like this. You must have gone to church once. Didn’t you get married in a church? Listen, George, listen to me. Didn’t you get married in a church?”
“That was a long time ago.”
The effort of answering broke the rhythm of his rocking—for a moment he was silent. Then the same half-knowing, half-bewildered look came back into his faded eyes.
“Look in the drawer there,” he said, pointing at the desk.
“Which drawer?”
“That drawer—that one.”
Michaelis opened the drawer nearest his hand. There was nothing in it but a small, expensive dog-leash, made of leather and braided silver. It was apparently new.
“This?” he inquired, holding it up.
Wilson stared and nodded.
“I found it yesterday afternoon. She tried to tell me about it, but I knew it was something funny.”
“You mean your wife bought it?”
“She had it wrapped in tissue paper on her bureau.”
Michaelis didn’t see anything odd in that, and he gave Wilson a dozen reasons why his wife might have bought the dog-leash. But conceivably Wilson had heard some of these same explanations before, from Myrtle, because he began saying “Oh, my God!” again in a whisper—his comforter left several explanations in the air.
“Then he killed her,” said Wilson. His mouth dropped open suddenly.
“Who did?”
“I have a way of finding out.”
“You’re morbid, George,” said his friend. “This has been a strain to you and you don’t know what you’re saying. You’d better try and sit quiet till morning.”
“He murdered her.”
“It was an accident, George.”
Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed and his mouth widened slightly with the ghost of a superior “Hm!”
“I know,” he said definitely. “I’m one of these trusting fellas and I don’t think any harm to nobody, but when I get to know a thing I know it. It was the man in that car. She ran out to speak to him and he wouldn’t stop.”
Michaelis had seen this too, but it hadn’t occurred to him that there was any special significance in it. He believed that Mrs. Wilson had been running away from her husband, rather than trying to stop any particular car.
“How could she of been like that?”
“She’s a deep one,” said Wilson, as if that answered the question. “Ah-h-h—”
He began to rock again, and Michaelis stood twisting the leash in his hand.
“Maybe you got some friend that I could telephone for, George?”
This was a forlorn hope—he was almost sure that Wilson had no friend: there was not enough of him for his wife. He was glad a little later when he noticed a change in the room, a blue quickening by the window, and realized that dawn wasn’t far off. About five o’clock it was blue enough outside to snap off the light.
Wilson’s glazed eyes turned out to the ash-heaps, where small grey clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried here and there in the faint dawn wind.
“I spoke to her,” he muttered, after a long silence. “I told her she might fool me but she couldn’t fool God. I took her to the window”—with an effort he got up and walked to the rear window and leaned with his face pressed against it—“and I said ‘God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me, but you can’t fool God!’ ”
Standing behind him, Michaelis saw with a shock that he was looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving night.
“God sees everything,” repeated Wilson.
“That’s an advertisement,” Michaelis assured him. Something made him turn away from the window and look back into the room. But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.

“That drawer—that one.”

But conceivably Wilson had heard some of these same explanations before, from Myrtle, because he began saying “Oh, my God!” again in a whisper—his comforter left several explanations in the air.

“I have a way of finding out.”

“He murdered her.”

“She’s a deep one,” said Wilson, as if that answered the question. “Ah-h-h—”  

He began to rock again, and Michaelis stood twisting the leash in his hand.  

“Maybe you got some friend that I could telephone for, George?”  

This was a forlorn hope—he was almost sure that Wilson had no friend: there was not enough of him for his wife. He was glad a little later when he noticed a change in the room, a blue quickening by the window, and realized that dawn wasn’t far off. About five o’clock it was blue enough outside to snap off the light.  

Wilson’s glazed eyes turned out to the ashheaps, where small grey clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried here and there in the faint dawn wind.  

“I spoke to her,” he muttered, after a long silence. “I told her she might fool me but she couldn’t fool God. I took her to the window—” With an effort he got up and walked to the rear window and leaned with his face pressed against it, “—and I said ‘God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me, but you can’t fool God!’”  

Standing behind him, Michaelis saw with a shock that he was looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving night.  

“God sees everything,” repeated Wilson.  

“That’s an advertisement,” Michaelis assured him. Something made him turn away from the window and look back into the room. But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.  

---
