LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. There was something magical about those journeys—the way the train would push through the snow-covered plains, the crisp air biting at the windows, and the sense of home growing nearer with each passing mile. The world outside seemed to slow down, wrapped in a quiet hush, as if even nature paused to honor the season.  

I remember the excitement that buzzed in the carriage, the way strangers exchanged smiles, bound together by the shared anticipation of reunions and festivities. The farther west we traveled, the more the landscape opened up, vast and untamed, a stark contrast to the crowded streets of the East. It was as though the land itself was breathing, stretching out beneath the pale winter sun, indifferent to the small lives that scurried across its surface.  

At home, the holidays were a time of warmth and nostalgia. The house would be filled with the scent of pine and cinnamon, the fire crackling in the hearth, casting long shadows on the walls. My father, ever the quiet presence, would sit in his armchair, reading the paper, while my mother fussed over the decorations, insisting that everything be just so. There was comfort in the familiarity of it all, a reassurance that some things remained unchanged, even as the world outside shifted in ways I couldn’t yet understand.  

But even then, I sensed a certain melancholy beneath the cheer. The holidays had a way of sharpening the edges of time, making the past feel both achingly close and impossibly distant. I would think of friends I’d left behind, of the person I’d been before I went East, and wonder if I’d changed too much—or not enough. The West, with its open skies and endless horizons, had always seemed like a place of possibility, but now it felt like a relic of a simpler time, one I could never fully return to.  

And then there were the parties—the glittering gatherings where old acquaintances would ask about my life in the East, their eyes alight with curiosity. I’d tell them about college, about the people I’d met, but I could never quite capture the strangeness of it all, the way the East had a rhythm of its own, frenetic and unrelenting. They’d nod politely, but I could see they didn’t really understand. How could they? The West was in their bones, just as the East was slowly seeping into mine.  

Years later, I would think back on those Christmas journeys with a mix of fondness and sorrow. They were the last threads connecting me to a world that was already fading, a world of innocence and certainty. By the time I met Gatsby, I had long since stopped making those trips home. The West had become a memory, a dream half-remembered, just like the man himself—bright, fleeting, and ultimately out of reach.  

But in those moments, hurtling through the winter landscape, I had believed, if only for a little while, that I could go back. That home would always be there, waiting.

events.title: Ending Affairs: Jordan and Tom
detailed_summary: Before leaving, Nick feels compelled to resolve his situation with Jordan Baker.
He meets her and discusses their relationship and its aftermath.
Jordan listens impassively, dressed for golf.
She informs Nick she is engaged to another man, which Nick doubts but accepts.
As Nick gets up to leave, Jordan confronts him, accusing him of being the one who ended things ('threw me over').
She recalls their earlier conversation about bad drivers, implying Nick was another 'bad driver' she encountered and suggesting his proclaimed honesty was a facade.
Nick responds defensively, citing his age (thirty) as being past self-deception.
Feeling angry, regretful, and still somewhat attracted to her, Nick turns away.
Later, Nick encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue.
Tom confronts Nick about seeming unwilling to shake his hand.
Nick asks Tom directly what he told George Wilson on the afternoon of the murder.
Tom confesses he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car.
He justifies this by claiming Wilson was armed, threatening, and forced his way into the house.
Tom asserts Gatsby deserved it for running over Myrtle without stopping.
Nick recognizes he can't argue with Tom's distorted version of events.
Tom laments his own 'suffering', mentioning crying over a box of dog biscuits found in the flat he shared with Myrtle.
Nick concludes that Tom and Daisy are careless people who destroy things and retreat into their wealth, letting others clean up their messes.
He shakes Tom's hand, feeling as if dealing with a child, before Tom enters a jewelry store.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

events.text_segment:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the colour of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that, though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head, but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.
“Nevertheless you did throw me over,” said Jordan suddenly. “You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.”
We shook hands.
“Oh, and do you remember”—she added—“a conversation we had once about driving a car?”
“Why—not exactly.”
“You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.”
“I’m thirty,” I said. “I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honour.”
She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.
One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewellery store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.
“What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?”
“Yes. You know what I think of you.”
“You’re crazy, Nick,” he said quickly. “Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.”
“Tom,” I inquired, “what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?”
He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.
“I told him the truth,” he said. “He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—” He broke off defiantly. “What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.”
There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.
“And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—”
I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made…
I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

‘You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.’  

‘I’m thirty,’ I said. ‘I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honor.’  

She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.  

One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewelry store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.  

‘What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?’  

‘Yes. You know what I think of you.’  

‘You’re crazy, Nick,’ he said quickly. ‘Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.’  

‘Tom,’ I inquired, ‘what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?’  

He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.  

‘I told him the truth,’ he said. ‘He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—’ He broke off defiantly. ‘What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.’  

There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.  

‘And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—’  

I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made. . . .  

I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewelry store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever."*  

*(The Great Gatsby, Chapter IX)*

*"There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair. She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the color of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that, though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head, but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.  

‘Nevertheless you did throw me over,’ said Jordan suddenly. ‘You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.’  

We shook hands.  

‘Oh, and do you remember’—she added—‘a conversation we had once about driving a car?’  

‘Why—not exactly.’  

‘You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.’

He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—’ He broke off defiantly. ‘What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.’

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I had made up my mind, and I knew that if I didn’t do it now, I never would. The weight of it had been pressing on me for days, ever since the funeral—since that terrible, hollow moment when I realized that Gatsby’s dream had died with him, and no one had really cared. 

I had to see Tom Buchanan. 

It wasn’t that I owed him anything—far from it. But there was something unfinished between us, something left unsaid that needed to be spoken aloud, if only for my own peace of mind. I wanted him to know what I thought of him, of the careless ruin he and Daisy had left in their wake. Not that it would change anything. People like Tom never admit their faults. Still, I had to try. 

I found him at his club, just as I expected. He was sitting alone in the lounge, a drink in his hand, looking as solid and self-assured as ever. The sight of him made my stomach tighten. He glanced up when I approached, and for a moment, his expression flickered with something like surprise—or maybe guilt. But it was gone in an instant, replaced by that familiar, condescending smile. 

“Nick,” he said, raising his glass slightly. “Didn’t expect to see you here.” 

“I won’t stay long,” I said, standing stiffly in front of him. 

He leaned back in his chair, studying me with those cold, arrogant eyes. “What’s on your mind?” 

I took a breath. “I wanted to talk to you about Gatsby.” 

His face darkened. “That’s over and done with. No point dredging it up.” 

“Not for you, maybe.” 

Tom’s jaw tightened. “Listen, Nick, I don’t know what you think you’re doing, but if you’ve come here to accuse me of something—” 

“I’m not accusing you of anything,” I said, though my voice was low and hard. “I just want you to know that I saw what happened. I saw all of it. And I know you did too.” 

For a second, he looked almost uneasy. Then he laughed—a short, dismissive sound. “You’re being dramatic. Gatsby got what was coming to him. He was a crook, a bootlegger. He had no business—” 

“He loved her,” I cut in. “And she loved him, at least for a little while. But you and Daisy—you just used people. You took what you wanted and left the rest to rot.” 

Tom’s face flushed with anger. “You don’t know what you’re talking about. Daisy’s my wife. She always has been, and she always will be.” 

“Is that why she ran to Gatsby the moment she had the chance?” 

He stood up abruptly, his chair scraping against the floor. “That’s enough. You’ve said your piece. Now get out.” 

I didn’t move. “You killed him, Tom. Maybe not with your own hands, but you set it in motion. You told Wilson it was Gatsby’s car. You knew what would happen.” 

His eyes were like ice. “Wilson was a madman. If he’d gone after Gatsby, that’s not my fault.” 

“Isn’t it?” 

We stared at each other for a long moment, the air thick with tension. Then, with a slow, deliberate sip of his drink, Tom sat back down. “You’re sentimental, Nick. That’s your problem. You see tragedy where there’s just life. Gatsby was a fool, chasing after something he could never have. And in the end, he paid for it.” 

I felt something inside me go cold. There was no reaching him. He would never understand, never feel remorse. He was untouchable, wrapped in his wealth and his certainty, forever shielded from consequence. 

“Goodbye, Tom,” I said quietly. 

He didn’t answer. 

As I walked out of the club, the weight in my chest didn’t lift. I hadn’t expected it to. But at least now I knew—some things couldn’t be fixed. Some people couldn’t be changed. 

And with that, I turned my back on West Egg for good.

events.title: Final Departure and Meditation on the Past
detailed_summary: Upon leaving, Nick notes Gatsby's house remains empty, the lawn overgrown.
He observes a local taxi driver who often points out the house, speculating the driver might have witnessed the accident and created his own narrative.
Nick avoids the driver, not wanting to hear speculative stories.
He recalls spending Saturday nights in New York, haunted by the vivid memories and sounds of Gatsby's parties.
One night, he sees a car arrive at Gatsby's house but doesn't investigate, assuming it's a late guest unaware the party is over.
On his last night, Nick visits Gatsby's house one final time.
He finds an obscene word scrawled on the steps and erases it with his shoe.
He walks down to the beach and lies on the sand, observing the closed shore houses and the Sound.
As the moon rises, the landscape seems to dissolve, leading Nick to contemplate the 'old island' as seen by the first Dutch sailors – a 'fresh, green breast of the new world'.
He reflects on the vanished trees that made way for Gatsby's house, symbols of the lost American dream.
Nick thinks of Gatsby's initial wonder at Daisy's green light, how close his dream seemed.
He concludes Gatsby didn't realize the dream was already behind him, lost in the vastness of America.
Gatsby's unwavering belief in the 'orgastic future' is highlighted – a future that constantly recedes.
Despite the elusiveness of the dream, Nick acknowledges the persistent human impulse to strive towards it ('run faster, stretch out our arms farther').
The chapter, and the book, ends with the image of humanity struggling against the current of time, constantly being pulled back into the past.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

events.text_segment:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. One of the taxi drivers in the village never took a fare past the entrance gate without stopping for a minute and pointing inside; perhaps it was he who drove Daisy and Gatsby over to East Egg the night of the accident, and perhaps he had made a story about it all his own. I didn’t want to hear it and I avoided him when I got off the train.
I spent my Saturday nights in New York because those gleaming, dazzling parties of his were with me so vividly that I could still hear the music and the laughter, faint and incessant, from his garden, and the cars going up and down his drive. One night I did hear a material car there, and saw its lights stop at his front steps. But I didn’t investigate. Probably it was some final guest who had been away at the ends of the earth and didn’t know that the party was over.
On the last night, with my trunk packed and my car sold to the grocer, I went over and looked at that huge incoherent failure of a house once more. On the white steps an obscene word, scrawled by some boy with a piece of brick, stood out clearly in the moonlight, and I erased it, drawing my shoe raspingly along the stone. Then I wandered down to the beach and sprawled out on the sand.
Most of the big shore places were closed now and there were hardly any lights except the shadowy, moving glow of a ferryboat across the Sound. And as the moon rose higher the inessential houses began to melt away until gradually I became aware of the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors’ eyes—a fresh, green breast of the new world. Its vanished trees, the trees that had made way for Gatsby’s house, had once pandered in whispers to the last and greatest of all human dreams; for a transitory enchanted moment man must have held his breath in the presence of this continent, compelled into an aesthetic contemplation he neither understood nor desired, face to face for the last time in history with something commensurate to his capacity for wonder.
And as I sat there brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby’s wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had come a long way to this blue lawn, and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it. He did not know that it was already behind him, somewhere back in that vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.
Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that’s no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further… And one fine morning—
So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

I spent my Saturday nights in New York because those gleaming, dazzling parties of his were with me so vividly that I could still hear the music and the laughter, faint and incessant, from his garden, and the cars going up and down his drive. One night I did hear a material car there, and saw its lights stop at his front steps. But I didn’t investigate. Probably it was some final guest who had been away at the ends of the earth and didn’t know that the party was over.  

On the last night, with my trunk packed and my car sold to the grocer, I went over and looked at that huge incoherent failure of a house once more. On the white steps an obscene word, scrawled by some boy with a piece of brick, stood out clearly in the moonlight, and I erased it, drawing my shoe raspingly along the stone. Then I wandered down to the beach and sprawled out on the sand.  

Most of the big shore places were closed now and there were hardly any lights except the shadowy, moving glow of a ferryboat across the Sound. And as the moon rose higher the inessential houses began to melt away until gradually I became aware of the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors’ eyes—a fresh, green breast of the new world. Its vanished trees, the trees that had made way for Gatsby’s house, had once pandered in whispers to the last and greatest of all human dreams; for a transitory enchanted moment man must have held his breath in the presence of this continent, compelled into an aesthetic contemplation he neither understood nor desired, face to face for the last time in history with something commensurate to his capacity for wonder.  

And as I sat there brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby’s wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had come a long way to this blue lawn, and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it. He did not know that it was already behind him, somewhere back in that vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.  

Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that’s no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms farther… And one fine morning——  

So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.  

---

This passage concludes Chapter IX and the novel itself, encapsulating the themes of lost dreams, the passage of time, and the elusive nature of the American Dream.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. The once-vibrant mansion, which had thrummed with laughter and music, now stood silent, its windows dark and unseeing. The hedges, once meticulously trimmed, had grown wild, their branches twisting like the fingers of some forgotten specter. Even the marble steps, where so many guests had stumbled drunkenly in the height of summer, were cracked and stained with neglect.  

I paused at the end of the driveway, looking back at the place where so much had happened—where dreams had been spun and shattered in equal measure. The green light at the end of Daisy’s dock, which had once seemed to Gatsby like a beacon of hope, was now just another light on the water, meaningless without his gaze to give it significance.  

The parties had ended. The crowds had dispersed. The whispers about the man who had thrown them had faded into nothing. Gatsby’s name, once murmured with awe and curiosity, was now spoken—if at all—with the detached indifference reserved for yesterday’s news.  

I thought of him then, standing alone in that vast house, surrounded by the ghosts of his own making. The suits in his closet, the unread books on his shelves, the imported champagne gathering dust in the cellar—all of it had been for her. Every extravagant gesture, every reckless display of wealth, had been an offering to Daisy, a plea for her to look at him again the way she had before the war.  

But Daisy was gone, lost to the safety of her old money and the hollow comfort of Tom’s world. And Gatsby—well, Gatsby was gone too, in every way that mattered.  

The wind picked up, rustling the overgrown grass, and for a moment, I could almost hear the faint echo of jazz drifting from the house, the phantom laughter of guests who had never really known him. They had come for the spectacle, for the champagne and the music, but none of them had stayed to mourn.  

I turned away, walking toward the waiting train that would carry me back to the Midwest. Behind me, Gatsby’s house loomed like a tomb, its grandeur now a monument to the futility of his dream. He had believed in the green light, in the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. But the truth was, he had been chasing something that was already behind him, something that could never be reclaimed.  

And so the grass grew taller, the paint peeled, and the world moved on, as it always does. Gatsby’s dream had been beautiful, but it had also been a lie—and in the end, even the lies we tell ourselves must wither and die.  

The train whistle blew, sharp and final, and I stepped aboard without looking back.
